titleStmt.title: Huon d'Auvergne, Kupferstichkabinett 78 D 8 (olim Hamilton 337) Annotations

div.note: 1] Holtus ("Considerazioni") published lines 1-109; his edition is a diplomatic one (45-48), with abbreviations reproduced and word divisions as in the manuscript. Tobler published lines 1-111 (pp. 617-19); he reproduces the text without punctuation other than the final periods and the lines that mark caesura here at the beginning of the poem, and without distinguishing u/v.
12] MS: une (final -e is expunctuated)

21] The initial here is very faded; the external background is gold, the internal illustration is red with a figure inside, so the original would seem to be blue, though it is currently faded and purplish.
55] MS: quilens with "il" expunctuated

76] Tobler omits the superscript after ".iiii."; Holtus seems to have a small "m" over the roman numeral. This MS abbreviation appears only with ".iiii." (six times) and would seem to be validated by line 6271, when in a prayer Christ arose after 4 days; and in line 11057, where four men are chosen as electors for the king to replace Charles Martel, and listed immediately thereafter. Furthermore, the "m" in lines 9334 and 11496 has no final upstroke.
86] ster: seems to here be a conjugated verb. Cf forms stent and ster (these last as infinitives) in the poem.
97] sorage: 'brother-in-law' (T-L serorge)
106] T 106: una chasa che Ynida la vite de longo, which might make more sense, "that Ynide saw from afar."
109] End of Holtus's diplomatic transcription ("Considerazioni").
111] End of Tobler's edited selection.
136] All text that is written above the line in the original is enclosed in parentheses in this transcription.

139] MS is missing a word for "horse"; since the phrase is a fixed formula (see lines 1182, 7290, 7297), here we insert "civals" to accord with two of the other three uses of "crenu" and its forms. "Destrer" would be another possibility.

167]There seems to be a problem with this line. In B "lou" normally means either 'place' (MSF lieu) or 'the' (MSF le). Here, however, a verb seems to be missing; perhaps, similarly T 168: luy et Ugon, this should be "lu o," 'he with'.
168]timbre: this is a psaltery, not what one normally expects for a call to fight. Perhaps there is a metathesis of the "r" for "t[r]ombe"; T 169: el feze i lifante e le cinbale sonare
200] This line is problematic for sense; the Turin version is also unclear.
231] pis: the reading is clear in the MS; yet see T 230: fora solamente quando el vole dal re lo presio [except when he saw the valor of the king].
234] T 233 does not include this wording: anzé se fereno de coro e de fede [they hit each other spiritedly and in good faith].
245] MS: revser
320] engoler: Cf. Holtus Aliscans v. 7560.
339] en gajer: en gage, as security, in case of misbehavior.
343] MS: nolōs. This is an interesting slip: non added to a form of voloir or perhaps merely a saut du même au même (two strokes plus 'o': no volons, but an extra syllable is not needed here).
402] vancel: see T-L vanerie; cf. Petit Robert vanne (dated 1274).
405] For the forms glese, glesse, glesie, see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 341).
415] MS: ia belist. belist is a hapax. Elsewhere in the text, we find l'abelist, e.g., 4169, 6321, etc.

498] gamentoit: Cf. Entrée d'Espagne, gaumenter (T-L gaimenter), but also 9746 here, "gamenta de soit," 'he complained of thirst'. It is possible that this is a combination of "gemere" (to weep, lament) that DELI dates before Dante, before 1321, plus "lamentare," or possibly with a frequentative created on "gemito," the past participle of "gemere."
508]There is a "+" in the right margin in light brown ink, perhaps inserted by a nineteenth-century reader.
533] MS: hastivement: there seems to be a problem with the tradition at this point; T reads (according to Rajna) "studevelmente."
542] MS: gamēt, with a side-ways "u" over "g" toward the "m"
610] Alternate reading: si l'afier spiera, "if they suspect the affair/event"; cf. T 605: se l'afar spiarà.
669] MS missing the abbreviation mark here in acoplir; cf. Vv. 1271, 1282, etc.
674] The MS is difficult to read: 'r' of complira is unclear. It would seem that there is something above the line, but the section is faded. Turin, v. 669: acompirà.

704] There seems to be a problem in these lines. It may be a case of saut de même au même, with "re" omitted; compare Turin line 702. In T 696, the verb is in the second plural, and "vuy" is the subject: vuy dovite esere signore lo mazore.
715] la added for sense and syllable count; cf. T: 709 lizeramente la porite vuy possa avere.
751] pregant: the "g" has an unusual form; it looks more like a "y"

752] e hescïant: Turin reads a bona fede e yntenzione, "with good faith and intention"; other appearances of a (h)esiant/ (h)esient here are a preposition with a noun, "knowingly, with good intention."
759] MS: alot; probably missing the abbreviation for "n"; cf. lines 1013, 7909, for forms of "aler" plus the present participle; so here would read alon t devisant, 'as they were setting up'.

790] MS: empial. Cf. vv. 47, 73, 373, etc., where we see emp[er]ial. However, see empir in the Prise de Pampelune (v. 4970) and the many other variants. As one of the most frequent words in epic vocabulary, it is greatly varied in rhyme. Furthermore, in Italian, "empio" means "irreligioso, sacrilego, profanatore" and "spietato, crudele" (Zingarelli) so while there is the hint of emperor, there is also the sense of merciless, sacrilegious ruler.
802] seinté: this seems to be a combination of "seinté" and "è," 'holiness is'.
810] m'en: the n is very evidently effaced, while all the other letters around it are clear.
818] MS: abosdivoir. Cf. Entrée d'Espagne: bosdeor; Guerra d'Attila: bosder, bosdeor, bosdera, bosdie, etc.
888] MS: confortas ɾoe
923] Tutore: cf. www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/tuttora_(Enciclopedia-Dantesca)/. Typical of Old Italian, found in Dante, the Fiore, etc. Consulted Nov. 26, 2016.
941] baor: cf. T-L "baudor" (col. 887), with lenition of the intervocalic occlusive.
948] MS: monreç
9452 hor cf. T-L "or, ëur," cols. 1163-64; Matsumura "or2, eur"
954] MS: il che. Alternate reading: ch'e il diable traïtor. / Le ont... (that he is the traitor devil. / They chased him out...).
960] Note the Italianate construction of definite article + possessive.
977] haïr: this could be haïr, anger, but we are interpreting it as "air" to go with the Turin reading and also the sense here: out the window and into the air, the sky.
1041] 1041] Ni anch portant: anch inserted in "neportant" (T-L col. 593; cf. Matsumura "néanmoins").

1062] This laisse is included in Tobler, p. 615. He does not always resolve abbreviations as here, always using "n" for the titulus indicating a nasal. There are no substantial differences in transcription.

1092] Caton: here refers to the Distichs of Cato, Disticha catonis: Quote from Catonis distichorum, Book 1, 8: Nil temere uxori de servis crede querenti; Saepe enim mulier, quem coniux diligit, odit [Believe nothing blindly of a wife complaining about the servants; For often a wife hates the one the husband likes]. Text and translation provided by Jim Marchand at http://faculty.georgetown.edu/jod/texts/distich.trans.html.

1149] la is almost unreadable in the manuscript. It is unclear whether this was intentional or not on the part of the scribe or was done later; it seems to be something painted over those letters, but similar to a spot on the left side of the page of a chocolate or cafeaulait color.
1152] Catchword at the bottom of the page, almost entirely washed out:si
1159] There are three other forms (aflicions twice, aflicion once), all in rhyme position. Therefore I here presume aflicion as the base form, here elided with the preposition a.

1174] Vulgate Psalm 118, l. 133: "Gressus meos dirige." All translations of the Bible are taken from The New Oxford Annotated Bible with Apocrypha (Expanded version), Revised Standard Version (NY: Oxford UP, 1977). There it is Psalm 119, p. 753, with translation given in this translation.
1180] Transcribed by Tobler, lines 1180-1220 (pp. 615-16). We note any substantial differences here. As noted above, his resolution of abbreviations differs; thus, "Par moy" for line 1218, etc.

1250] Between lines 1249 and 1250 in column 9Va, running into the right margin is a line with an "x"; also at the bottom of column 9va, there is a line with a corresponding "x" in the left margin. Since the column is one line too long in comparison to the other, and normally the columns are equal, this final line (1264) is clearly to be moved to the position between 1249 and 1250.
1295] This laisse is also transcribed by Tobler (pp. 616-17); again we note any substantial differences of transcription.

1300] This line is problematic; we are interpreting as a separated future (ti ho dire = ti dirò). T has difficulties with it as well, with a substantial difference in reading: line 1287 Se zò mantene che tu ai dito i[n] to s[er]mone, ("If you continue that which you have said in your speech"); cf. diroy (vv. 1246, 1944, 2422, 2448), in rhyme position.
1329] Tobler: uoire / non poit. MS: voie
1356] MS: tot. This section is difficult to read; the initial of the following line seems to have been changed from a "T" to a "C."

1361] "Sir désigne la ville de Tyr, puisque les tissus d'Orient étaient réputés et ... l'on indique volentiers une ville d'Orient comme lieu d'où provient un tissu précieux" ("Sir" refers to the city Tyre, since oriental fabrics were famous and a famous city of the East is frequently used as a source for a valuable fabric (Vallecalle, trans. LZM)).
1390] The Latin "Magnificat" text runs, "Magnificat anima mea Dominum," "My soul magnifies the Lord" (Luke 1.46). Here the scribe (or redactor/author) says, "Magnify my soul, O Lord."
1399] MS: ma[n]da na, however it seems most likely to be an error for "via[n]da na"; cf. line 6181 viande n'a
1523] Celor: the initial is an unusual shape, between a "C" and an "L."
1541] MS: q eloiaute; an nseems to be elided, which would have read: Q'en loiauté
1559] chareme: interpreted as "carême," fasting.
1667] In the rhyme position, the verb "savoir" takes this unusual form.

1698] MS: riponse; cf. forms of reponser (v. 2505, 2690, etc.). Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," notes a possible analogue to this episode in Renaut de Montauban, where a local citizen informs the knight that the city is besieged by Saracens (pp. 18-19). That similarity is continued in that both refuse to rule the kingdom and each is sent further on, Huon to the Holy Sepulcher and Renaut to Brindisi.
1707] MS: constatinople
1711] MS: afie đs (crossed 'd' and long 's' above the line between 'a' and 'f')
1726] glorie: this is the most frequent form in the text when the word is written out; even with the resolution "gloire" the syllable count is high.
1748] trainé here is the infinitive, missing the final -r ; that is how T understood the line. Alternatively it could be v'oit trainé, "the kings had there dragged before them."

1749] The MS is damaged at this point and extremely difficult to read, but the digital copy clarifies the reading; the tradition was problematic, since T's reading is quite different: morty zasere al sabione dead men lying on the sand. If the reading here were similar, it might be hon veit sor ce gravois; but the two are not always parallel. Gravoy appears appears five times, gravois once, meaning "sand" or "gravel" in some way (path, etc.) in this MS. The two emendations made here both address common errors: a missing stroke and an incorrect connector between strokes.

1753] The beginning of this column is faded in parts, though the outlines of strokes are clear. For multiple minims, there can always be doubts, but in searching other F-I texts there are no forms of sui- for the verb "to follow," whereas there are 68 forms of siv- attested in FIOLA. RIALFrI however, offers both. In this text there are 3 other forms with siv-, one seut, but none with sui-.
1798] guioner: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 346), "guide"
1807] esclaris: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 307), re esclarir and the change of conjugation in Franco-Italian.
1830] MS: giat

1855] Note that this column is one line shorter than the following, and there is a flag rising from the illumination below into the column. This poses interesting questions as to the order in which the work was done.
1881] MS: nos
1910] enci: cf. Holtus ( Lexikalische p. 290), "ici," 'here'
1914] MS: et. The word et seems out of place here; we emend to e' (for "I"). Cf. T line 1911, Homo sonto de Carlo Martelo.

1975] Note the theme of a vow while on a quest; his ancestor, Guillaume d'Orange, vowed not to change his clothes, wash his hair, eat meat or stew; he won't drink wine or liquor, kiss anyone, or sleep in a bed, until he returned home with Guibourc; he too drinks only water and eats only rough bread (Aliscans; for an English translation, see Ferrante). Guillaume will be Huon's guide in Hell, as we will see.
2022] Turin differs substantially here: se luy lassa ora, el parerà a questo ponto "if he leaves now, it will be evident at this point" (T 2015).
2111] This line is missing from Turin. It is problematic; "sovent" elsewhere here is the adverb; however "sovenir" appears and other forms of the verb.

2115] Between les and afi at the end of the line is a hole in the MS; afi seems to be written deliberately after it; there does not seem to be any letter missing. J.-C. Vallecalle suggests that it might have been an a there possibly scraped off?, making the line read Posible çonse il fust, bien le sai a fi, that is, "This [Huon's mission in Hell] would be possible, I know certainly (... if Hell were built on earth)."

2130] gieter may have been the original reading of the text, for "how to shoot a bow"; or this may be a form of "guerrer" to fight, since many Franco-Italian texts have forms of "gere" and "gerer" for MF 'guerre' and 'guerrier'.
2142]MS: une hom (emended)
2145] MS seems to be missing the abbreviation for n:m'acontent; cf. v. 747
2152] See Turin line 2126: Se p[er] devin miraclo non m'avene
2154] These 6 lines are very difficult to read due to the ink being worn.
2159] aquitier: there are 16 forms beginning with aquit- (and one other following d') compared to 9 that are clearly quit-, so we have divided those following d as beginning with the vowel.
2175] MS: resont with a caret below to insert a tiny p written above the line.
2186] n and u are frequently very similar in the MS. Ansi is perhaps also possible or intended.
2195] MS: Bout
2197] For the construction in genoillon, see Holtus (Lexikalische pp. 338-39).
2208] galon: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische p. 334), "côté," 'side'
2230] With 2227 the prayer moves to the New Testament; Simeon is in Luke 2.25-35.

2431] Nunc dimittis: beginning of the Canticle of Simeon, said in services of evening worship such as Compline, Vespers, and Evensong. The full verse is 'Nunc dimittis servum tuum, Domine, secundum verbum tuum in pace,' "Lord, now lettest thou thy servant depart in peace, according to thy word."
2232] Lazarus appears in John 11.1-44.

2233] Te Deum laudamus: "Thee, o God, we praise" is the beginning of the so-called Ambrosian hymn, authorship attributed to Ambrosius or Augustine, traditionally ascribed to the fourth century CE. The name can also refer to a religious service of thanks, as seems to be the case here. The second half of the first verse of the hymn, 'te Dominum confitemur,' "we acknowledge thee to be the Lord," seems to be echoed in the following line here, as does the general context of the hymn to save His people.
2244] âbandon="a abandon"

2319] This line is problematic: T does not have an equivalent. Turin 2306 reads, "né ponto el [con]te né quily ch'era [con] luy," 'not at all the count nor those who were with him', so with a different initial (in fact in Berlin, the initial "L" is odd; it could be an "N" with a short initial upstroke. In that case, it would be something like 'Nor did Huon cease to pray.' However, nowhere else in the text is there a "Ne pas" in this sort of structure.

2320] ne laist: there seems to be a missing pronoun here– or some other error. "Ne" can be the first person plural object pronoun, but would require changes to direct discourse: qu' "il ne ne laist periler," possibly because of a saut de même au même. Turin has a slightly different version, with a change to direct discourse in the following line and the verbs in first person plural– but also with an object pronoun in the line equivalent to this (T 2307-08).
2362] Psalm 51: "Have mercy on me, O God," a psalm requesting, among other things, "Let the bones which thou hast broken rejoice" (8).
2384] Veriteç appears twice (5504, 11099) and veritere once (6308) to one verté (8736), so we resolve here as we do.

2393] MS: loge. T: fora la bona fede e la crosse ch'el adorava (v. 2379). Visibly, "loge" doesn't fit the rhyme of the laisse, - oie. If it read "loe" or "lie" from "louer," to praise, the sense would be clear and follow Turin, thus the emendation.

2412] aveit a bone foyseems to be a MS error with either an extraa(he had good faith or he went in good faith) or perhaps a u for an n (aneit as some form of "andare"), though there is no such form listed in RIALFrI for other Franco-Italian texts. Cf. Turin, "vene a bona fede..
2433] nos: Final letter is an odd shape; could be noç
2440] The phrase sans poy appears to be equivalent to "sans plus", "without adding anything further."
2446] We believe thatsavra is like the use of Modern Standard Italian "sapere," "to taste": "it seems (it tastes) like..."
2449] Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," pp. 19-20, compares these Laisses 93-96 to the Roman d'Alexandre (ed. Harf-Larcner), pp. 464-69.
2500] Compare T, line 2484: grande e derupossa p[er]ché ponto son li agradise. The Entrée d'Espagne has "graïr," but this form doesn't appear in RIALFrI.

2519] Brown ink through theor of d[e]morr[re]. mal has a line above it; it is not the standard abbreviation for r or vowel + r, and there are no other abbreviations with l, so its resolution is not immediately evident.

2545] Note the rhyme not for sight here. The form "stanch" appears also in the Entrée d'Espagne and Aquilon de Baviere, so this seems evidently a deformation for the rhyme, and demonstrates that the final sound was - n.
2566] Compare T, line 2542: Quando e∙l vede avrire la gola ch'el vede el fogo apredre; B seems to be understanding vait for both verbs, baër and esprenda[n]t.

2602] T has understood this differently, line 2584: "I praise [him] willingly (with good heart)." This could also be the meaning here, in which case the preceding line would end with a comma instead of a semicolon.
2611] l'asent: this could also be il la sent, "he felt it" and so T understands it: molta greve la trova, l. 2593.
2614] M: lö tēptz. This seems to be an unusual case of assonance alone, not rhyme.
2622] After tost, scratched out letter in the MS.

2642] De profundis clamavi ad te Domine / Domine, exaudi vocem meam: Vulgate Psalm 129, modern Psalm 130, "Out of the depths I cry to thee, o Lord! / Lord, hear my voice!" mixed with Psalm 101/102 (where line 2 is "Domine, exaudi orationem meam") or 142/143, which begins with that same line: "Hear my prayer, Lord." They are all three among the penitential psalms.
2670] Eripe me [de inimicis meis], Deus: Psalm 58/59, line 2, "Deliver me [from my enemies], O my God"; it is also a verse 9 from Psalm 142, seen above, one of the seven penitential psalms.
2681] There is a letter scratched out after il before atant. This folio in general has many corrections.
2684] si stoit: they had to, they needed to; cf. T 2665: Quando lo zorno li mancha se ly coventa albergare.

2687] li jorner: This expression can mean "journey" or "day" in Old French. In Italian, it might have that meaning (DELI, 13th century), but "day" is the first and more frequent meaning. It is difficult to say which is intended here.
2689] ge inserted above the line.

2702] marois: in OF this is defined as "swamp," but that is problematic for this text. For the difficulty of "marois," here, and possible meanings, see Morgan, "Cent ans de franco-italien : du Huon d’Auvergne de 1341 au Huon d’Auvergne de 1441," https://phaidra.cab.unipd.it/detail/o:452058?mycoll=o:452059 (29 Dec 2020).
2719] doine: this is a hapax, perhaps a scribal error for "dame" that appears 193 times. Cf. T line 2700, done, 'women'.

2733] As frequently occurs where there is a syntactic or lexical problem, this line does not appear in T. The initial "A" causes a problem, since it would seem that their behavior/appearance demonstrates that they are afraid; without it, there is no subject stated for the sentence. We presume that the verb is plural, as in the following lines.

2745] Stengel's review of Brockstedt includes this laisse in a note, pp. 160-61 for the Berlin text. He uses square brackets for additions, parentheses for things he believes should be omitted. Included here are lines where he does either. Not noted are differences in uses of written accents.
2747] Stengel (Review, p. 160): ce q(e)'armés
2755] Stengel (Review, p. 160): [e]n est

2757] Note the use of n here for "nous" (ne before vowel) object form. This is typical of early Italian texts. See Rohlfs, Morfologia, paragraph 460. This is a legal formula meaning in the presence of witnesses. Stengel notes the appearance of Drusiant, a character in the Bovo story, in this laisse, but also that the King of Dalmatia in this line is not in the Bovo story, where Macabrun (sic) replaces him, but in Bueve (French version) he plays a role in freeing Josienne (Bovo's Drusiana). The Bovo story is complicated by many versions in the European tradition; see Morgan, Geste Francor pp. 76-105, for a comparison of the versions. There is no clear link between that Drusiana and this princess here.
2761] âutre: for 'a autre'
2764] Stengel (Review, p. 160): Qu(e)'aveque
2777] Stengel (Review, p. 161): E [va]
2778] Stengel (Review, p. 161): (por)forma
2789] MS: Lort; the final letter seems to be an anticipation of the following word's final letter. T: Alora se ne vene al maro [...]

2790] “relever des fonz” / “tenir sur les fonz” are technical terms relating to baptism; baptism here is not done in a way not strictly in keeping with ecclesiastical law, for the two ladies are standing godparent to each other. This is particularly odd because when the servant raises her mistress from the baptismal waters she is still not baptized herself.

2796] End of the selection transcribed in Stengel's review. "Valence"(and variants) is a well-known female name as well as a city name; cf. Foucon de Candie (RIALFrI), and also heroine of a lost romance, Seguin and Valensa (cf. "A chantar m'er de so qu'ieu no volria" by Beatriz de Dia, v. 10, and Arnaut de Marueil,"Tant m'abellis e.m plaz" (v. 166).
2805] ên: e(t) + e + en, "and he is in"; cf. T 2874: che Dio abia marzede de luy [et] i[n] drito sentero li mande.

2806] This line is problematic; it is not logical that Huon asks the women what to do next. In fact, in the Turin MS, it is they who ask him: T 2875: Como la faremo?" le done al [con]te domandano ["How will we proceed?" the ladies asked of the count]. Perhaps the line should be emeded: "Com la fareç, ami?"
2818] MS: ci ņait. Though the n is expunctuated, it seems to be necessary for the meaning; see translation.
2821] MS: vos vos pri ne mie: second vos and ne are expunctuated.

2840] herbolant: we do not find this verb attested anywhere else. "Erber" appears in T-L (for the past participle, used with flavoring a drink) and Matsumura (both for the T-L meaning and for "faire paître"). The image is one of farm animals, eating grass in a pasture. There are other forms based upon HERB- and ERB- in this text, but no others like this one.

2854] See the illumination on the following page (f. 21R) for an illustration of the bill; "guie" is not clear in meaning; it is a hapax legomenon as a noun in this MS. The other six forms mean "he guides, leads." Thank you to Kelly DeVries who gave the name to the "pichon" as a weapon; see the "Additional Notes" for further information.
2880] MS: pelle. p with a line above is always p[re] and thus is so transcribed here.
2890] marois: see note, line 2702 above, and Additional Note
2909] Abbreviation line very light in the MS.
2911] MS "vait" seems to be a form of "valoir."
2928] MS: me devroit
2956] çausi: see Holtus, Lexikalische, p. 248: "GI çausir «distinguer, voir», got. KAUSJAN."
2961] dagier: probably omitted titulus for "dangier", which appears five times elsewhere in the MS. "Faire dangier", 'résister' (Matsumura); cf. T-L.

3032] rapegon: we are interpreting this as derived from RI + A + PLICARE (cf. MSI "piegare"); however, see T 3006: vene y[n] rampgon; see the illumination here at the bottom of folio 21v, where the lion is lowering its front half before Huon's sword. A similar expression does not appear elsewhere as far as we can determine. "Rampare," 'to rear; to climb', would not make sense here (though missing tituli for nasals are frequent in Franco-Italian) since the first hemistich states he was afraid to rise. If this is a nonce creation or a hapax, T may have misunderstood and related it to "rampare."
3046] MS: alieç: CF T-L 278-279 alegier, "to be eased, lightened"; Folco di Candia> V19, l. 1581
3065] The laisse initial here has a face sketched into it.
3075] MS: sa seori; asseürer/s'asseürir (T-L)
3116] The "good companion" in the kin_g of beasts contrasts with the king of men, Carlo Martello.
3158] quoy=coi="tranquille," T-L "still"; s'ora derives from orer "anwünschen"="wish"
3163] dela : "over there," not "by there," so one word. There are many appearances of this construction in rhyme position.
3171] MS: mont le sen (le expunctuated)

3179] sor: this is one of two appearance of the lexeme at rhyme position; the other is a toponym (v. 4613), which this is clearly not. Normally it is the preposition (from Lat. SUPER) followed by an object; it could here be an adverb with a similar meaning, and in T 3148: desopra (though the passage is somewhat different) reads thus. However, "sor" can also mean 'golden brown, reddish brown' (T-L from a Old Frankish *saur), especially of hair or horses, or, by extension, 'dry' or possibly 'dark' (as opposed to sunny), which is how the translator has rendered it here.
3193] segure: DELI scure, segure before 1292, derives from SECŪRE(M), Latin. One wonders if this is the otherwise unidentifiable "guie" mentioned above in 2853.
3200] Funny face drawn into the capital for this laisse, as for many in this section of the MS.
3228] This version differs from Turin where it is the serpent that cries out.

3251]As Meregazzi notes, this section resembles the Roman d'Alexandre where Alexander finds a demon imprisoned and asks the way out (ed. Harf-Larcner, pp. 470-77; Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," p. 20).

3257] derumeç: a verb with this form does not appear in OF, in OI, or in RIALFrI. However, "desrompre" in T-L, from DIRUMPERE (cf. various forms in RIALFrI), 'to break apart' and "deruinant", 'precipitous', (T-L desrüiner) both appear, and here some combination seems to come into play. Turin uses "butaremo zosa," 'we'll throw down'. See then 3266, "l'en ont fait ruiner."

3262] Or va pur a giter. This is one case where the French and Italian constructions differ but the meaning is approximately the same: "by rolling he was going to move it" and "by rolling he was going to toss it."

3286] For this section, cf. Le roman d'Alexandre, Branche III, laisses 160-162, part of the "Dangerous Valley" where Alexander confronts a demon in order to leave. (Harf-Lancner trans. of E. C. Armstrong, pp. 470-477).
3354] Here Huon addresses the figure aloud.
3361] The MS seems to be missing the abbreviation for an "r" here: archiere, "archer," as in vv. 1710, 9216, 11662, 1204 archiers.

3383] Quilidés: At this point it is unclear to whom this might refer. One suggestion is that this might deriving from Bacchylides (ca. 518-ca. 451 BCE), a Greek lyric poet who was included in the list of nine lyric poets. Longinus, for example, praises him, which might account for his name being familiar if not his poems.
3398] This might be a reference to Dante's hell: those inside the walls of Hell (Canto 10) cannot see the present and see the future only dimly (10.94-105).
3408] Note that this column is shorter than most by one line: it is only 36 lines long.

3445] stropoit: a metathesis from Italian "storpiare": 'impedire', 'to hamper' attested 14th century (DELI). Two uses of an str- form are attested in other texts: Aliscans, stropez 'portare in esilio' (from 'storber'); and Attila, stropie, 'to rub' (from 'stroppicciare'), neither of which seem likely here.

3503] MS: oi ge, with ge expunctuated, the g with a dot above, the e with dot both above and below. "Natural" i.e., from a liaison outside of marriage, and therefore not legally an heir (though a woman as an heir held varying positions through the eras and in different locations).
3506] MS: Moit veut. There seems to be a copying error here; perhaps some kind of saut, for "Mout me veut." T 3465: Mo vedite, is also problematic.
3522] MS: lemme
3556] defoissé: cf. defois, T-L "Abwehr, Verteidigung", 'defense', though it gives no verb based upon it. Cfr. FEW "defensum."
3678] Emendation for MS nōs avōs; note the use of the first person plural as subject.
3686] MS: geste beste

3691] The grammatical structure here is unclear; this is the only sere form in the text. The people (or their spokesperson) are using "tu" with Huon, so it seems unlike that this is "seré" = 'by us you will be honored'; perhaps this is the "tu" form. On the other hand, using a conjugated verb after a preposition is also unlikely; see Turin, "mostra-ne la via p[er]ché seremo tuty salve", 'show us the way so that we will all be saved', where the conjunction is used. Thus we have left the line as is.
3750] Cf. Turin, line 3704: quando y[n] mia vita tanto ben fato averò
3763] si seiron could also read s'iseiron, "they went out"; there are no similar forms for "to sit," and Turin has them sitting down, "putting" themselves at the table.

3809] There is a confusion here and in the following lines between the number of people: Huon, Sanson and Anseis. Turin has eliminated Anseis so that the plot is simpler and the action easier to follow. Verbs and adjectives vary back and forth between singular and plural. It does seem that Huon and Sanson are the ones conversing here.
3838] alor could also read a lor, "to them." Cf. T 3801: a le soue done

3852] This is a very Italian episode; the city-states in the Peninsula regularly exiled members of a losing party, who then ran coups from neighboring cities. The Medicis, for example, in 1433, were exiled from Florence, only to return the following year after a change of government. The constant wars of the fourteenth century in the northern Italian Peninsula reflected the various parties representing different interests changing allies and strength.

3862] MS: e par: this line is problematic. T reads Ugon y[n]tende la parola p[er] un paisante, "Hugon heard the dispute through a local person [alternatively, a passer-by]." The sense would seem to indicate that Huon informs himself of the reason for the dispute by speaking with a local person. Whether the abbreviated "p" here in B indicates some form of parler with a missing "l" or not is not evident.There are no other forms of parler without the "l" so we are leaving the line as it stands.

3867] MS: mō: -o- was changed from -e- (the edge of the loop is still present) and there is a line to the right of the vowel not quite totally removed. MS: Trespasemant, with a line sketched before the "mant," which is rare; it seems to be a scribal error for "niant"; this sort of joining of strokes occurs frequently (cf. Holtus, La versione franco-italiana della "Bataille d'Aliscans: Codex Marcianus fr. VIII [=252], p. XXV, XXXV-XXXVI).
3886] acest: cf. V4, ed. Beretta, açil, açellor; he suggests the influence of Old Provençal (Il testo assonanzato franco-italiano della "Chanson de Roland": cod. Marciano fr. IV (=225), p. 384).
3907] MS: vons
3932] ba: from bäater (T-L): "spähen", 'peer, peek'
3952] MS: el (inserted above the line)
3979] peis: this is one of the cases where it signifies OF "pas"; the line is 4+6 syllables, so no dieresis is needed.
3995] See T 3956: chi aveva, 'that had'
4012] The tenses here seem to be simple past rather than present perfect equivalents, since there are no auxiliary verbs in this line. Thus in the following line en is the preposition alone.

4024] ferir: the construction here is a little odd; perhaps this should be emended to fereor (combattants), that appears at two lines (though always in rhyme). This line would then be in apposition with the preceeding one, with two absolutes.
4041] q'e·l'ost = "qe en l'ost"; cf. T 4002: che y[n] l'osto atrovà sono
4119] T 4079: De zorno y[n] zorno quanty y[n] naserano (line 4079); it would seem that the Italian writer did not understand the text.
4137] engres = enge (T-L "Geschlect, Sippe, Art"; Matsumura, "race, espèce")
4138] MS: fable pece hom

4160] ni'l Crucifis: it is unclear here whether "crucifis" means the crucifix itself or the person crucified upon it; this varies in the poem. Since Yhes is mentioned before, we presume it is the crucifix itself, though the term also means "the crucifix."
4180] agraïs: from "agreër"
4204] This is Psalm 133, verses 1-2; Dante also quotes it in his Monarchia, Book 1 (English: On World Government).

4240] The right, by definition, is the "good" side, whereas the left is that of the devil; cf. Dante's Inferno, where the visitors must progress to the left (with two exceptions). See Durling and Martinez, eds, Inferno, (Oxford: U Press, 1996), p. 153 n132.
4254] The following line (4212) in T reads, "con più marinary chi menauna grosa nava.
4260] poine non: Again, this passage seems corrupted. Perhaps this represents peinant, 'taking pains', that is, to avoid capture or death.
4290] te[re]rre: This is unusual, perhaps the adding of an unnecessary abbreviation mark when the full word is already present.
4317] pes: T-L, "Jammer", 'misery'
4347] desrogemant: desroiement/desreëment, T-L 'Unordnung'

4360] Cf. Matthew 7.14, "For the gate is narrow and the way is hard, that leads to life, and those who find it are few." Vulgate: "Quam angusta porta, et arcta via est, que ducit ad vitam: et pauci sunt qui inveniunt eam!" If we were to transcribe Stroite ert la voie qui no l'atient a tant it would reflect an Italianate structure with a tanti: "Stretta è la via che non l'ottiene a tanti" or "non la tiene a tanti"– "that not many can hold to it' "or "that not many can succeed at it."

4407] This is a complicated passage, with non-standard forms. These two lines (4406-07) are not present in T, which compresses difficult segments. While many forms of "roman- " derive from "remanoir" (cf. Mainone, Formen, pp. 30-31 for F-I ar- where OF has re-/ri-). Here however, we do not see any way for that to work. Definitely a locus terribilis! Alternatively, the previous line might read "de niens qui..." (for niens, see 5482) and here "qu'el roman iça" - translated, "There is nothing that one might want to buy, / Plenty, we must believe, if he stay here."

4408] MS: il g[ra]nt pechieç il fa; we have omitted the first "il" since it is one syllable extra (it makes 13 in the line) and it is not necessary. Cf. T 4360: Se zò fano p[er] vanagloria, gran pecha lor fa.

4418] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio") includes from here these laisses 164-174, line 4664. She uses a capital letter only for new sentences, not at the beginning of each line, and does not note resolution of abbreviations. Any substantial difference in transcription (i.e., not capitals, her resolutions or her standard word division) will be noted. She does not use quotation marks here, so direct conversation is not evident, though she does later in the passage transcribed.
4424] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): ata[c]ha
4437] This line is missing from Turin, as are many confusing lines.
4440] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): comenciet le jor
4466] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): qui l'ont
4469] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): oille istrent
4482] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): le menton
4503] The first hemistich of this line seems to be a repeat of 4501 above; in Turin, however, the two also repeat. so it is clearly part of the tradition.

4509] charene: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 251), "cherene: affection"; he cites also Gui de Nanteuil "carine," so we seem to have a combination of the two here (cf. also Matsumura, "cherine," citing Entrée d'Espagne). But the word also appears in line 1560; between the two, it seems here to mean "penitence," and in fact, Turin reads "gran quaresema fay, ancha no[n] vite la simele" (line 4461), with "Lent" as the original derivation.
4513] flagelle: Cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 326), "flageller, fouetter," 'to whip'
4514] roelle T-L 'roeler'
4515] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): dapne elle; êlle = est elle

4538] Istrent, istront appear a number of times in this text; aman this once, but also in Attila, where it is defined as "subito" IX, 254. T clearly did not understand: li stre[n]ze la man, "he shook his hand."
4555] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): por ice
4570] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): un quartier de pem

4573] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): ostalaisent; there does not seem to be any record of a similar verb, more likely ostà (past participle of "oster" or "ost[el]er") + a form of the verb laisser = 'well-lodged'. Cf. Turin line 4524.
4589] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): n'a nil de voir
4592] somons: from "semondre/somondre" (T-L col. 413)

4597] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): feroi ge. Her word division does not alter the meaning, the verb remains present conditional, first person; the ending is frequently -oige for that form (see Mainone, Formen, pp. 15-17; Laut, p. 49).
4614] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): mille visque, mant en la sor. However there are no forms "visque" in the MS, and frequently "jusque" (with its abbreviations) has a similar form.
4617] There seems to be a problem with this line. It is missing from Turin, and the rhyme is the same as the previous line, "ancor." 4566 T: quy sono de tuto el mondo la fiore (for both 4617-4618).
4640] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): qu'il vit; our meaning here is *qu'il le vit, subject pronoun plus object pronoun.

4651] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): pam bescuit; she also notes, "corr. anone in avoine." In this text, it does frequently appear in the context of the horse: vv. 6402, 7011; v. 107, anons. However, in OI, "annona" was food distributed to the population periodically (DELI; attested end 12th century).
4652] asié comes from aasier (T-L), 'to reassure'
4657] atapinament T-L atapiner, 'vermummen', 'to disguise'
4662] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio"): qu'il en gardast
4664] Meregazzi ("L'Episodio") stops here to pick up again later.
4665] Tobler transcribes lines 4665-4672 (p. 619).

4669] Stengel includes this section in his "Eine weitere Textstelle," numbering it 4669-5008. The initial here is large and heavily decorated, as well as being in gold leaf. There is decoration across the top of the folio and down the left margin as well, indicating the beginning of an important new section.

4692] The end of the line could also be interpreted fai ces demostreison, but since Turin reads "fazy demostranza" we construe it this way. There are no other forms faicés; faige and faigés are related to "fatigué," but there are three faice tokens from "to do/to make."
4698] Stengel ("Eine weitere"): dau [sien] consoil

4703] Catchword after this line: A YnideAt this point begins the inserted signature, and Turin differs. It is clear that there is a problem in sense; there are supposedly five messengers, of whom two are mentioned in Turin (vv. 5652-53), these first two here; they are sent to Ynide and she rejects them in two laisses that are not present here. The ambassadors complete an initial embassy that is refused, and then at line T 4706, the equivalent of B 4704 picks up. Among those mentioned with the ambassadors, at various points, are 15 names: Ruçer/Rugier; Teris; Henri/Enri d'Aubespine; Belençer (marchis); Morant d'Autefoie (relative of Rugier and the Archbishop); Gui de Barcelune; Conte Gallerant d'Arthois; duc Tholomeu/Tholomeis; Uger de la Savine; Gauter de Clervant (queens); the Archbishop of Mainz (Maance); Saudin; Aumeri; Galerains de Bertagne; and Riçars, le sir de Normandie.

4704] The previous line, at the end of folio 32V, ends with the catchwords A Ynide which do not then begin the next folio or signature. These first two lines are problematic also, since a verb is missing; there should be something like "There is" or "There was." There is a space in the MS after "arcives" that seems to be scraped; something is visible around the edges. With ultraviolet, one can almost see "q" and "e", and maybe something above the line too, "qe" with "u" above the line? Or just a bit of chalk solution or whatever they used. The line has far too many syllables, yet the word is missing its ending. Thus we give this as an emendation. Stengel ("Eine weitere," p. 39): L'Arcives[ch].
4739] MS: plais

4745] The reading Tholomé here is problematic, since Tholomeus has not been designated head of the band of ambassadors or otherwise much discussed until now. MS T, line 4745, reads "Servire debe esere tal sire [et] de grande [et] de menore"; perhaps the original here was "tal ome" (such a man), referring to the king, perhaps referring to the king. There are two possible avenues for distraction, the first written, and the second oral. In the first column of this folio, in line four (this is line 3 of column two) in line 4707, "Tholomeu" appears, so could have distracted a copyist. If the scribe were writing under dictation, he might have thought he heard"tol ome" instead of "tel ome," and would have added the "h" after the "t" because he had just encountered the name earlier [with thanks to colleagues for confirmation].

4760] Note the use of courtly love terminology, as in Marie de France's "Lai de Chevrefeuille,""Bele amie, si est de nus: ne vus senz mei, ni jeo senz vus," the words of Tristan to Yseut (Lais de Marie de France, ed. Karl Warnke, rpt., Paris, Livre de Poche, 1990, p. 266).
4766] Stengel ("Eine weitere," p. 41): fil econtre
4787] The end of this line and the next are missing in the MS.
4799] MS: selong
4812] impacer: cf. MSI "impacciare" (DELI: from OF empeechier, from Late Latin IMPEDICĀRE; DELI).
4835] MS: peçe=OF "pieça"; Stengel ("Eine weitere"): Lle

4839] MS: il est: since both cortoisse and insenne are feminine forms, and the line is twelve syllables as it stands, this must be feminine (with sinalephe), for Ynide, whose actions are in fact described in the following lines (PEB).
4866] MS indeed reads bein.
4871] Langlois lists Teris as Lord of Vermandois (p. 668).
4881] çassons: cf. v. 4831, "la çasons"; this line could also read "por chel di", but there are no other "chel" forms for "quel" in this MS.
4920] This line is incomplete in the MS. These laisses are not in T, so there can be no reconstruction from that text.
4928] MS: un êve since êve is always feminine in this text="une eve."
4933] This is the point at which T picks up the story again, T v. 4776.
4934] MS: potē

4939] armara: 'will remain' from "remanoir/remaindre". In northern Italian, due to the widespread loss of atonic vowels, consonant groups coming together fostered the development of anaptyctic vowels, even in initial position, particularly when voiced consonants were together; thus for example, Jacopone da Todi, "armane" for rimane (Rohlfs ¶ 338). For the meaning, see Salvioni, "Annotazioni lombarde. III. Annotazioni lessicali," p. 427: e.g., "per nu no roman," 'non dipende da noi', 'it doesn't depend on us'. In this text appear both more standard forms and these.
4940] Something is clearly missing in this line, perhaps de [servir] vos? Cf. T 4782: de complire la vostra volontady.

4976] In the Entrée d'Espagne, line 15795 "brais de justisse" also appears, as in Gui de Nanteuil, v. 2921 and Guerra d'Atilla, bk 1, v. 92. The second expression appears only in Gui de Nanteuil, v. 2920, Aubre de vertus. They seem to be fixed expressions; the arm of justice, like the arm of the law, can refer literally to a statue. These sound like fixed expressions, perhaps from well-known documents at the time.

4978] This line is incomplete in the MS. In MS T, v. 4820 reads "Ay, cristianità, como ay tuo onore p[er]duto!" There is a little ink following perduto but it may be merely bleed-through from the back.
5008] End of Stengel's "Eine weitere" transcription.

5012] This line is incomplete in the MS. In MS T, v. 4851 reads "Dona," dize Berardo, "che loro lasate-ly y[n]trare." There is clearly a difficulty with this line, though the general idea is clear: "Lady," said Berardo,"may you allow them to enter."
5034] MS: jambaseors
5047] coreste: cf. Holtus, Lexikalische p. 99, who cites the ending of -estre as a comparative construction in the Entrée.

5048] Calisor: an unclear reference. There are references to "Caliburn," (Calibor) Arthur's sword in Geoffrey of Monmouth (also"Talibor"; Flutre). However, this seems to be a person; perhaps it is Hector des Marres's foster brother, Colestant (Meliadus, ed. Levy) ?Rois de Guineste: Guineste is usually Winchester, so this would be King Arthur.
5049] Patroclus was given to Achilles's father, who placed the two together. Achilles and Patroclus grew up together. Hector killed Patroclus at Troy. They may have been lovers.

5053] MS: colleste: hapaxlegomenon; could this be some combination of "con" and "este," a tonic pronoun? Perhaps through scribal error of writing two strokes unconnected somewhere along the line? Since it is in rhyme, it could be a distortion of "(a)llestire", placed together with another form? Or, "con lei sta": cf. 4889 T, "che lì state", 'that you stay with them'; but this would mean a repetition of "with."
5083] Unusual abbreviation form: empeos with a sign over "e" and "o-" or perhaps a two-part sign?
5112] MS: serees; the second e has a tiny dot below and a bigger one above; not clear though if it should be expunctuated. We have done so here.

5124] The blue capital here is unusual in that it is not decorated at all with filigrees. Normally the red capitals are decorated with purplish designs and the blue with red; here the capital is bare and simple.
5132] MS T 4955: vuy avite p[er] vuy tramiso, [et] zò e my y[n]seme siemo. ensoine : cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 300-301), "scusa," 'excuse.'.
5150] cum: the final "n" here is the "vertical m" found in Latin texts. Cf. CPLEDTM, Fasc. 1, p. 28.
5172] We understand strine related to "estriner, estrener," "frapper" (T-L, col. 1474, ironic use; cf. Matsumura).
5185] Cf. 2503, "faim et soy li destringne."
5192] For the construction with irer, see Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 352-53).
5231] nel= in + il (cf. Modern Italian)
5233] MS: ētase

5242] This line recalls frescoes and statuary of hell where souls are balanced on a scales to decide their fate, with devils sometimes cheating by leaning on the scale or otherwise influencing the weight so that angels cannot take them to heaven.
5264] ont âcompagner = ont a acompagner, "must accompany"; cf. "avoir a + inf., auxiliare servant à exprimer l'action qui doit être accomplie" (Matsumura 331); T-L column 758.

5311] aclinan: "acliner" and various forms of it appear in the MS; perhaps a form of it is here deformed for the rhyme. Turin v. 5127 "Berardo, Morando et Y[n]rigo ynsanble seno" and the last word has been changed.

5329] Tobie: This may be a reference to the apocryphal book of the Bible, Tobit. It praises the purity of marriage, and is thus particularly relevant here. There are northern Italian versions of the text (cf. Maria Carla Marinoni, ed., La versione valdese del libro di Tobia, Biblioteca della ricerca, Traduttologia 2 Fasano di Puglia: Schena, 1986).

5363] MS: avon. MS T, lines 5179-80 read: "che avante m'averoy lo coro fenduto / e l'anyma de my del tuto avere peruta" ...for I would first have my heart split, and my soul completely lost (i.e., be dead) before I would ....
5371] crevant, from "creventer" 'to strike down, knock down' (T-L cravanter, gravanter, Column 1016; REW crepantare).
5379] fortese: Cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 329), 'force'
5399] MS T 5212: chi non fosse y[n] vergogna de l'apele, who is not ashamed to call him
5404] topinelle: cf. http://tlio.ovi.cnr.it/T-LIO/ "Gravato da una situazione difficile, da un dolore emotivo, da una pena amorosa; misero, infelice, sventurato"; frequent in exclamation, Oh ....!

5430] This line is somewhat problematic, evoking different reactions in those thinking of Italian and those thinking of French.trasumans: cf. Dante Par. 1, 70. This would be one of its earliest usages after Dante (DELI: before 1321, Dante, first use) if that is what it is. But as PEB points out, "de suor" is 'with sweat' (cf. vv. 2504, 5027, 6821) so the preceding word is probably a rendering for "tressüer," 'to sweat in big drops'. The "suelee" then remains to solve; there is no similar other expression in the MS. There are forms of "svelleir," 'to be awake, to awaken', and that seems most likely here. In RIALFrI, "suel" forms are primarily from the verb 'to be accustomed to,' not an adjective 'alone.'.

5432] Note that here Ynide anticipates the cries of those in hell; see v. 7661, 8848, etc., reflecting too the later comment that life is a is a purgatory for those who suffer it (v. 2398), and the self-beating repeats Huon's gesture to himelf before the temptation of the sorceress (laisses 269-70, vv. 6882-6929).

5439] Ynide's men include her relatives and various vassals. Twelve names appear: Alisant d'Aquitaine; Galudins, the porter; Thomas, Baudoin, Berart, her relatives; Ulien/Elin; Teris; Gauter d'Estampes; Robert and Anseis; Corberan and Sanguin. There are also a few minor figures: Grailet, Melians e Gralant. The name Morant appears on both sides: among Huon's men and with the ambassadors. There are also multiple appearances of "Teris" and "Thomas" in various forms.

5443] One wonders about the significance of the holy figure here. Mary Magdalene was famous for being very rich and "sensuous pleasure keeps company with great wealth" before meeting Jesus (Golden Legend , "96. Saint Mary Magdalene," Jacobus de Voragine: The Golden Legend, Readings on the Saints, trans. William Granger Ryan, vol 1 (Princeton: U. Press, 1993), pp. 374-83, at p. 395. Perhaps Ynide is attempting to imply to Charles Martel's representatives that she has repented of her disobedience. Her feast day is July 22, so it may be merely a mark of time.

5445] Saint Helen was the mother of Constantine, who went to Jerusalem and the toured the Holy Land, supposedly discovering the True Cross. She also founded and beautified various churches. She brought various relics back to Rome, and down the street from St. John in Lateran is her Basilica of the Holy Cross in Jerusalem, where her head graces a classical statue, near the Aurelian walls. The floor was originally with dirt brought back from the Holy Land; thus perhaps the appropriateness of such a site here for Ynide's prayer and its particular appeal to Christ.
5447] MS: baroine. The second and third strokes are clearly linked at the top and the first and second at the bottom.

5450] A vernacular rendering of portions of the Credo (Nicene Creed). Unlike the "prière du plus grand péril" [prayer of greatest peril] that warriors use before battle, Ynide does not here invoke various Old Testament figures, but rather the redemption from original sin.

5460] MS: sa aubçēt ("b" also has a titulus over it). We emend here in part because of syllable count and in part because of sense: "sa aubercent" does not make sense: it is either two verbs together or a singular possessive pronoun plus plural verb. As frequently is the case for problematic lines, it is missing from the T version.

5467] Following this line, T has an additional line, 5277: Ynida dize un salmo ch'ela trovò yn lo salterio [Ynide said a psalm that she foumd in the psalter]. Alternatively, there would be a repeated direct object: E quant le prevoire le voit, le magne sire [And when the priest, the great lord, saw it]. But the archbishop is nowhere else called a "great lord," and what is being seen (sospir is masculine; her, perhaps? Or perhaps "And when she saw him, the priest, the great lord," but then why the "And" that begins the line? Clearly, there seems to have been a bit of a confusion here in these two-three lines in the tradition.
5478] reïre: from the prefix RE- + ire

5479] Candace is the wife of Darius of Syria in Roman d'Alexander; she falls in love with Alexander the Great. She figures in Roman d'Alexandre Bk 3. See Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," pp. 19-22 on other Alexander romance derivations in the poem, though she does not discuss the Ynide embassy episode, and Morgan, “Le Roman d’Alexandre dans Huon d'Auvergne: tourisme et truismes dans une épopée du XIVe siècle.” Alexander tricked her, pretending to be a messenger and not himself, though he then revealed the trick and spent the night with her and then left– as Aeneas also left Dido. So Ynide is suggesting what might happen to her.
5482] MS appears to read niiēs
5491] Lachebire: unknown figure. Not in Moisan, Langlois or Flutre.
5514] ait: we understand as a form of "to help" based upon T l5324: Dio aiute da mia parte che più l'averà biasemato, though in general in B "ait" is a form of "avoir."

5532] The forms here are unlike others we have seen in this text; and these lines are omitted from the T MS. We have interpreted sorer as "suer" and scaulir as "echauffer" through an Italianate "caldo" since Ital "scaldare"=to burn, though one might expect opposite expressions. The T text (in a different order) does mention the 'fire of love,' v. 5346, "Lo feu d'amore sovente li fate sentire." Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 454-55), relates it to "essorer," with varying meanings according to the text; 'to relax, cool off.'.
5537] païr: this is a hapax legomenon in the text. It could be three verbs: to pay; to appear; to become pale.
5541] crosir: cf. Guerra d'Attila (Glossario: cf. croisir, "rompere, frantumare, ferire").
5555] MS: pālam
5559] tort: from "tordre," to turn, to treat; a sordois, T-L cols. 886-7, 'the worst'

5564] MS: dolonor. This line and the previous are difficult to parse. It's up to her, not to Thomas, her relative, to make the decision. Should it be lais here as related to "laiier" 'to leave, be permitted'?
5568] MS: empëo, where the descender of the p is also crossed.

5620] soies: seems to have a final consonant in order to maintain syllable count, since the only other forms of soies both follow the subject pronoun "tu" (vv. 1556, 6797), but personal endings are not consistent as typical in Franco-Italian texts.

5641] There is a problem with the tradition for this line. T 5429: che non dicha l'uno a l'altro rialmente a l'altro; so there is something beginning with "a" at the end of the line. We interpret it here as "laiier", 'abandonner' (T-L laiier).
5670] MS: susnel

5697] rue: in this MS, "rue" is either 'road(s)' or 'wheel' or a form of 'to throw', so this clearly is the wheel of fortune. T 5474: Ora l'alta sezia desopra la raina sederite, reflects a scribal difficulty: the strokes in the middle misinterpreted and a possibly (and frequently) missing abbreviation for 'n' added, so that 'rua' might have been interpreted 'rňa'. Since Saudin says the queen will be dead, being over her makes little sense.

5718] terllisse: cf. terlis, terlise, Entrée d'Espagne, vv. 1378, etc.; terliz, Gui de Nanteuil, v. 3198. Usually used of hauberks, trip-ringed; however, also for fabrics, three-thread fabric (T-L tresliz, col. 609). Though T-L defines it as "ein derer, fester dreifädiger Stoff" this is clearly rich material, not coarse.
5725] gaberisse: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 333), "raillerie," 'mockery, scoffing'
5747] MS: ɔpendre

5754] The references are missing from the Turin MS. The identity of "Sulliendre" seems to be Sulla, the Roman dictator, who worked with Crassus, the Roman general, member of the Triumvirate with Julius Caesar and Pompey (PEB).
5756] For Porus, see the Roman d'Alexandre, Branche 3, laisses 30-240.

5757] Pelias: King of Iolcus. This may refer to Pelias sending Jason after the Golden Fleece when he arrived at a ceremony for Poseidon with one sandal, having lost the other crossing a river (it had been predicted that one wearing one sandal would overthrow him). "The port of Endre" or "the port Dendre" would then be near Mt. Pelion, where Pelias was being raised by the centaurs.

5758] The meaning and derivation of desgrendre are unclear. Perhaps "sgrenre" (for the form, cf. genero=gendre; tenero=tendre etc.), 'to seed a fruit/remove bits from cob; recite the rosary; eat with glee'. PEB suggests a deformation for rhyming purposes of "desgarander" = "render someone helpless" (T-L Col. 1598 ). The concept, to do in someone, is clear.
5762] This seems to refer to an earlier embassy, present in Turin, but absent here in the B manuscript, unless it is referring to the previous day.

5784] decernus: seems to be a Latin ending on an OF verb, "decerner" (T-L col. 1243-44) (PEB). The author's identity is unclear. There were two famous Venetian Jewish commentators named Isaiah of Trani (the Elder and the Younger), (c. 1180 – c. 1250; 13th - 14th century). The time frame and region are appropriate but whether their works would be known in the Gentile community is unclear.

5786] Zenat: unclear to whom refers. In the Italian Aye d'Avignon, "Çenat" is given as the name of the poet (v. 798), which Callu-Turiaf annotates as a diminuitive of "Zeno" that was popular in the Veronese-Paduan era (p. 401).

5801] diablemai[n]s: not present in T-L, but Godefroy and Matsumura (citing FEW 3, 64a), give a noun; Godefroy, "the power of the devil (vol 2, p. 7070); "the devil himself" (Matsumura, "diablerie" (p. 1026)).
5805] Reference to Matthew 6.12 and Luke 11. 4, the second of which is closer: "Demitte nobis peccata nostra, siquidem et ipsi dimittimus omni debenti nobis" in the Vulgate.

5812] Disticha catonis Catonis distichorumI. 30: Quae culpare soles, ea tu ne feceris ipse, Turpe est doctori, cum culpa redarguit ipsum. Those things you are accustomed to blame do not do yourself; It is bad for a wise man when his own guilt comes back (to haunt him). Text and translation provided by Jim Marchand at http://faculty.georgetown.edu/jod/texts/distich.trans.html.
5813] This is a problematic reading; see note in translation.
5823] autor: this could be atour, "fine clothing" (T-L, col. 646), or hautor, "pride, cockiness" (T-L, col 1035)
5846] MS: mebruç; cf. me[m]bru, me[m]bre, me[m]brue in this text
5857] For the form se lagne, see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 358).

5871] braagne: T 5600, "bergagna"; T-LIO "bergagnare": 'tirare per le lunghe', 'draw it out too long' (first attestation, Matteo Villani, Cronica, 1348-63; from Prov. barganhar, OF bargaignier (DEI s.v. bargagnare); http://tlio.ovi.cnr.it/voci/005628.htm, 16 Dec 2020).

5878] cloroit: these last two lines are not present in T, so they, like many here, confused readers somewhere along the line. It might be "coloroit" (LZM; colorare appears before Dante, 1321, DELI, and a saut du même au même is easily imaginable; forms of it appear in other F-I texts, and the adjective elsewhere here) or perhaps "esclaireroit" (PEB; cf. T-L esclarir, esclarcir). However, "cloïr" exists as well, 'to enclose' (T-L col. 496, lines 39 ff.).
5926] esmatés: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 311), "terrasser, détruire," 'to crush, destroy'
5942] acuissient: from acoisier, aquisier "calmer" (Matsumura; T-L acosier see cosier, 'schweigen', to keep silent, remain still, col. 547)

5964] MS: dorit; T 5669: l'arcevescovo et Ynrigo e Morando che no[n] dormea [the archbishop and Henry and Morando who didn't sleep]; if we emended B to follow that, it would be "dormoit," but if they are leaving town, they wouldn't in any case be sleeping. If a syllable is missing here, from a saut de même au même, for "dorloter," the reading could be "q'e' non dorloit" [whom they (=Ynide's men) didn't coddle].
5968] baster:=Italian "bastare" to be enough, to suffice; attested 1253, DELI (unknown origin; no attestation in OF, T-L)

5979] avist: there are three tokens with this sequence of letters: 5601 and 7579 in addition to this line. In each case it is a form of the verb "to have," interpreted also by Mainone as avist (Formenlehre 24), similar to the forms in Entrée d'Espagne, Attila, V4, etc. As Veillard and Guyotjeannin's Conseils suggest, the alternation between "u" and "v" (avit and avait appear, as do aüst and aüstes, aüsés) suggests an interpretation with "v" (Fasc. I, 25).

5982] Ecce magnum is the beginning of the responsory dedicated to St. Martin ("Ecce magnum et verum sacerdotem ecce bonum dispensatorem" in the Ambrosian rite (http://cantus.uwaterloo.ca/node/219512, 17 Dec 2020). The expression appears subsequently in histories and in various Latin poems. We believe that "magnum" to reflect the responsory is most appropriate here. It is part of matins, so fits with the reference to "ancient prime" earlier (v. 5979).

5995] MS maçerie: the letter l seems to have been corrected in r (for "Margery"). While there is no "Saint Margery" per se, Margery (Marjorie) is an abbreviated form for "Margaret." While there is no Order of St. Margery/Margaret attested, St. Margaret was largely revered in the Middle Ages (hers was one of Joan of Arc's voices). T compresses these lines and in v. 5698 reads only that the woman was the abess at the "monastero ... Santo Giromia" [Jeremiah], suggesting that there may have been a scribal metathesis in transmission in addition other variations.

6014] pri: the word is normally a form of the verb "to pray, beg"; however the line here is at least a syllable short (5+4). T 5714: a pé a pé , 'on foot' (with redoubling for emphasis); one might reconstitute "a pi" (cf. V. 3083), which would allow 5+5 syllables
6015] MS: nuit demi .pl'. with a caret between nuit and demi .
6028] Tobler transcribes from here through line 6139 (pp. 607-609).

6064] See Psalms 24(25).7, "Secundum misericordiam tuam memento mei tu" [according to thy steadfast love remember me] and 50 (51).3, "Miserere mei, Deus, secondum magnum misericordam tuam" [Have mercy on me, O God, according to thy steadfast love]. (Biblia Sacra iuxta Vulgatam Clementinan Nova editio, 4a ed. Madrid: Biblioteca de autores cristiano, 1965; English as usual, NOAB. (With thanks to PEB.).
6067] Blank folio, Recto and Verso, follows.
6068] Meregazzi, "Prete Gianni" picks up her transcription here, her lines 6223-6552, here 6068-6397.
6088] en die: it is not clear here what Huon is referring to; T specifies "de my" (v. 5783). I could be "about it," the mission, or Huon's dedication to it (dying in mission).
6105] entre: from Latin INTEGRUM (T-L entre adj, col. 624, cf. entier).
6110] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 32): n'en cuit
6112] Tobler: de grant pri. sic. The print seems to be missing a letter at the end.
6117] MS: mais; an "s" seems to be written over an "i"; Tobler: mas; Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 34): m'as
6126] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 34): Si non.
6132] avenois: see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 224).
6139] End of Tobler transcribed section.
6158] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 36): fors qui l'en dure. T-L endurer, col. 304, "aushalten, erdulden"

6178] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 38) also includes only the final line as a quote. The main clause here is "non leisera.." followed by the clause "non face," so with a pleonastic "non" after a verb of intention.
6194] plus mes: "plus mieux"
6200] MS: son son signor
6221] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 40): Lors que
6226] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 40): qi conquis
6240] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 42): gardera li mon grant
6278] pecer: peçoiier/peciier/peceër ,'split, break into pieces' (T-L 538, l. 39).
6257] The storm and cold as a means of phyical suffering are a recurring narrative trope; compare the ambassadors as they head back to Charles Martel, vv. 6046-6053.

6287] Salve regina: one of four antiphons to Mary sung at different parts of the ecclesiastical year. This is sung at Compline from the Saturday before Trinity Sunday until the Friday before the first Sunday of Advent (since the thirteenth century), but is also spoken at the end of the rosary, and it figures in other important uses.
6288] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 46): la proiere

6292]In adiutorium meum: first verse of psalm 69 (70). "These words form the introductory prayer to every Hour of the Roman, monastic, and Ambrosian Breviaries, except during the last three days of Holy Week, and in the Office of the Dead" (Catholic Encyclopedia, https://www.catholic.org/encyclopedia/view.php?id=3808, consulted 19 Dec 2020). ONAB: "Be pleased, O God, to deliver me!"
6294] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 46): benig[n]e chiere
6296] Line incomplete; T 5987: charegò-le per vero lo francho conte, but there the previous line has Huon picking up his equipment only, so here hoisting it.
6297] MS: over it plu there is an ink smear.
6301] pere here for 'per', equal etc. (T-L cols. 698-707)
6304] ala Âgollant for Ala a Agollant; reference to Aspremont; Meregazzi: il ala a Gollant. See Extra notes for Aspremont.
6305] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 46): Hei Diex.

6319] plaseïs: Matsumura gives "swamp" (plasceïz), but T-L (plaissëiz, plessëiz, col. 1057, l. 1) and Hindley (plaisseis) give "hedge"; see T 6010: Quando fono oltra de ly grandy passe, so this is a difficult passage, perhaps a line of hills.
6337] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 50): le pieç
6349] golir: an Italian-based form; cf. Guerra d'Attila, "goloient"; T-LIO "goliare," 'desiderare'.
6350] MS: (t) is inserted above line with a caret under the line before the s is underpunctuated at end of the word.

6359] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 50): aré tinir. There are no forms "aré" or "tinir" in this text; "tenir" appears 25 times (5 with [n]). "retenir" in various conjugated forms appears numerous times, including "retint." Turin line 6050 read "retenire" in line-final position. The "a-" prefix is frequent in Franco-Italian, as noted above.
6362] In the manuscript, the final stroke of the –r is extremely light.
6366] Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni," p. 52): acrement
6393] MS: moy. Scribal distraction of following "soy"; cf. T6084 mé molto se dota de sé e de l'afare.
6397] End of Meregazzi ("Prete Gianni").

6398] Stengel publishes from here to line 6992. He notes in the introduction that he edits for reading ease: resolving abbreviations, differentiating i/j and u/v and adding punctuation. Any comments related to that edition will be listed by Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe"). Differences in editing style are not noted.
6400] mesay: T-L meshaigne=mahaigne=mehaigne, 'damage'

6408] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 687): qu'il conseut (with no explanation); MS: cōsent, very clear, but of course confusion between links for minims is quite possible. Quant que: quando che is a veneto expression according to Zingarelli 2018, for "quando, proprio quando," 'when, just when'.
6413] Meregazzi notes similarities here with the temptation of Perceval in the Queste del Saint Graal ("L'Ugo d'Alvernia,"p. 25).

6417] s'aregone: Cf. T 6108: s'araduna, 'to meet'; we are interpreting "aregone" as related to aringo T-LIO , "a place for meeting, a meeting" and extrapolate the verb as "to meet." DELI: ragunare, alternative of "radunare"; here with a typical a- prefix (RI+ADUNARE); cf. Rohlfs vol 1 ¶ 339.
6425] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 688): (!) At the end of the line, va[n]celles : another example of confusion downstrokes in "n" and "u"; cf. lines 402, 2868, RIALFrI, numerous appearances.
6437] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 689): "Que ferés...
6473] fanos written as one word in the manuscript, as usual for object pronouns following the imperative.
6475] astu written as one word in the manuscript, as usual for subject following the verb in question.
6484] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 690): Venuç [a] li
6486] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 690): enfer atrover
6495] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 691): luy [g]e

6503] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 691): Conten[t]eç moy; a scribe seems to have confused "contez" and "contentez," so 'Content me' and 'Tell me'. Since four syllables are needed but "contendre" and "contenir" appear here in various forms with their standard meanings, as does "contenter", we emend. Cf. T 6193: contentaty-my
6520] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692): de ci; "Ne" here is the negative non of MSI.
6522] ençaigne: trickery, cunning, wiliness (T-L engan, col 373; DELI inganno, 13th cent., cf ingegno, also 13th cent.)

6523] Mestre could be understood as a feminine plural here, in which case the comparison would be with other female necromancers. The line in general is tricky because the verb seems singular (soit) but tant would indicate a plural.

6531] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692) : efforç par. Cf. the Roman d'Alexandre, Branche 3, laisses 207-213, seeking the trees of the Sun and the Moon (ed. Harf-Lancner pp. 528-535). All references to the Alexandre will be to this edition and the format Branch, laisse(s) or verse(s).
6533] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692): Et qui distrent
6540] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 692): au roy (!) pooire; Roman d'Alexandre, Porus I, laisse 217, etc. for Porus.

6543]There seems to be a missing line here-- the end of one and beginning of the next. In T there are two additional half lines here to further explain their quandary: 6231-32 quando viteno no·l pono atrovare, / né nisuno trovono chi li sapesse y[n]signare, 'When they saw that they could not find it [the path] / Nor anyone who could show it to them'. "asenoire" 'to guide, to indicate' (T-L col. 577, lines18-45).

6549] Alexandre, l. 3189. There is clearly something missing here as well; in T, this appears as 6238 tute le spiziarie naseno y[n] quela abitanz(i)a, 'all the spices are born in that location'. Perhaps this is another case of end of one line and beginning of another missing.
6552] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 693): No(n) avons. This line is not present in T. The final term here, "provoire," seems to come from "porvëoir" (T-L): "to care for, provide for'
6554] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 693): qui [tant]ert
6558] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 693): Qu'ici. There are 15 appearances of "ici" versus 140 of "ci" so we have divided differently.
6568] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 693): et la dame en demin (emend)
6571] We are presuming a dative construction after "plaise" for a parallel with line 6573.
6572] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 694): Que mesremoue art (!)
6577] Presumably this means saying spells.
6578] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 694): a la vetre maison
6586] MS: ī ombre: there is clearly an abbreviation line over the "i" but it does not seem to make sense here. T has no "n." It may be to clarify separate syllables.
6607] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 695): Apalpe nos; since the rest of the discourse is in the second person plural, we presume this is too and accent the final syllable.
6611] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 695): sainç [nule] male
6623] Jâ = Ja a
6628] Viscardi (Letteratura franco-italiana, pp. 133-34) includes through line 6636.
6229] This would seem to refer to a hell similar to Dante's Inferno, where Lucifer is encased in ice. However, when Huon arrives to Lucifer, that is not the case here.

6633] li lusage: this seems to be a case of "concretion of the article": that is, lusage is a plural noun for "habits" or "customs." Cf. Rohlfs ¶341. Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 696), followed by Viscardi: si l'usage; the MS reads clearly "li."
6635] sorvage: T-L: sorvenir, hinzukommen, 'to ensue'; Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 696): so(r)vage
6644] MS: le isle; -sl- for -ll- is a frequent paleographical error. Cf. T 6333: la cità (PEB).
6645] Note the use of verbs of appearing or seeming rather than being.

6649] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 697): est açe; the letters are all written together, not separated. Though OF might suggest pillars, T understood "rooms" (stanzie, v. 6338). The form also suggests an equivalence with "estage," which might mean residences (cf. T-L: rooms; residences).
6653] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," 697): il [i] vont
6654] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," 697): reguardant
6658] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," 698): le charoill(e)

6668] Long epic comparison beginning here: victor after a tourney and his arrival. Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 698): ant .II. grant (beginning of line missing); Viscardi (Letteratura franco-italiana, p. 135), includes the entire laisse based on Stengel.
6670] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 698): gaaign[é]
6674] Viscardi: puign; T lo brando nudo [naked swords].
6676] MS: astu, written as one word
6684] Viscardi: mervoille ot
6687] Viscardi: soie venu
6688] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe"): Yesu! MS: yhu, with abbreviation line over the "h." Throughout, "Yesu" is Stengel's resolution of this abbreviation.
6696] E·maintes = 'En maintes'
6699] (e): written above the line, very light, no caret below. DELI: vanagloriarsi "vantarsi, essere pieno di sé," 13th century. Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 700): vanglorïer
6707] MS: Mes e non: expunctuated 'e' after the first word
6713] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 700): giant [i] vont

6717] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 701): l'estriver. This is the only appearance of the expression in the text, and "le" is written slightly apart from the following word; see introduction on vowel + s + consonant. Cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 319-20), "étrier," 'stirrup'
6729] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 701): Döes
6731] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 701): pas [ni] noise ni cri
6735] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 701): fiuç (de) Davi
6736] Matthew 27, 46; Mark 5, 34.
6741] Note the word order: le plus + noun + adjective.
6742] Compare the illumination at the bottom of this folio.
6755] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 702): salue[e]

6759] MS, Stengel: l'asist. This does not make sense, since the queen approaches him then speaks to him. Cf. T 6448: dapresso luy s'aseta e possa li rasona; it can be a banal error of misreading a written text to confuse "l" and the long "s."
6760] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 703): ne l'[av]oit

6766] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 703): devers, which normally means "in the direction of"; "de devers" would mean from the area of ("du côté de," Matsumura). Thus two words here, as they are in the MS.
6772] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 703): Qu[e] il
6776] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 703): Tant que [d] (l)'enfer aige (Tant que + subjuntive for 'Until')
6778] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): feütee (which would bring the line to 10 syllables); but cf. v. 4129, where two syllables are not necessary.
6779] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): desfiëe
6782] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): dame l'oit
6785] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): delïee; perhaps a better emendation would be "tot [li] delïee," for 12 syllables.
6795] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): enfer [la]

6800] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 704): g'estoie (in this text, there are two forms that are clearly "stoie"; two clearly "estoie"; two not clear, this and questoie, v. 10177, for the use of the initial e- before s+consonant).
6810] See Dante, Inf. 5, 112-122, for the joy to sadness trope, here reversed.
6817] (qe) inserted above the line with caret below, but very light with tiny letters, not visible in microfilm.
6819]See Scattolini on this section and the antecedent tales ("'Chorisantes itaque puniuntur'").
6823] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 705): Et retorne; perhaps possible since "avoir" is the auxiliary verb of the previous line.

6858] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 707): raïne
6864] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 707): s'embla
6867] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 707): embracé
6869] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 708): Aces

6891] peçé traitor: this could peçe traïtor, "worst traitor"; we have followed Turin's usage of "pechà traditor"; had it been "worst" Turin would have read "peçor" or something similar rather than "pecha" from Latin PECCATU(M). This narrative motif is again a repetition, this time of Ynide's beating herself after she receives the king's ambassadors (vv. 5343-5350). See Morgan, "The Passion of Ynide (I)."
6896] Stengel ("Keuschheitsprobe," p. 709): sentirés [dunc] d'un

The right side of the illumination at the bottom of this folio figures the scene in the lines at the beginning of the following folio: three angels descending to Huon, one holding a book open. Though the writing is not legible, it is probably intended to be "Gloria in excelsis" (PEB).

6993] Begin Stengel, "Suche" (his line 7148). He uses square brackets for his emendations/additions, and parentheses for his items to remove. He seeks to regularize the lines to 10 or 12 syllables, usually in comparison with the Turin version and Andrea da Barberino.
6997] aneslepas: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 292): "eneilepais," "immédiatement."

6998] las: it isn't clear to whom or what this refers. One option would be to Huon himself, since "las" in general either refers to a person or is an abbreviation for 'alas'; however, the forest is the nearer referrent here, and the expression is in rhyme.

6999] Stengel, "Suche" (his line 9154), notes tas here = 'Dickicht' [thicket, tangle]; he compares 'a tas', line 10361. However, that would make no sense in hell. T-L gives 'Haufe' [heap, pile, hoard] for tas; see T 6684: Passò la costa e la vale e lo paiesse. DEAF: ensemble de personnes ou de choses; boue; Matsumura: amas.
7006] Stengel ("Suche," p. 54): Baldras = Baghdad (citing Langlois)
7011] FEW: talevas, "bouclier en bois"; cf. Roman d'Alexandre "talavat/z" (RIALFrI, 22.XII.2017), from *TALAPACIUM (https://apps.atilf.fr/lecteurFEW/lire/131/35).

7031] c(h)ar: very light insert, with no caret below

7037] sto[r]né: Italianism, "stornare" (DELI, bef. 1300), "volgere ad altra parte," to turn to the other side, from tornare with the s- prefix from DIS- (DELI suggests perhaps on the model of OF "desturner"). To a French reader, it may sound like étonné, 'startled', which would also work in the context, making a perfect example of how F-I works with different publics. It may also be a combination for similar reasons.

7038] See illumination below; on left, ship with line tied to horse; on right, Huon fighting off the birds. Lots of blood, some birds in air, some on ground, and flock coming toward him. Cf. Roman d'Alexander again, for attacks near a pond (Branche 3, laisses 64-85) that include griffons that carry away horses (3, 66; Harf-Lancner pp. 368-87, esp. 370-71).

7062] chemis: this is the only appearance of the form in the MS. It is masculine, and there is one appearance of chemin with "prist" (v. 7156), but it is odd that this appear in the middle of arming himself. Two lines cover the same information in T, 6745-47: e luy lo spenze e ponze avè so chamy[n] presso./ Ferma(r)se sa de soe chamy bruno,/ prende le soe arme e lo scu dorato.

7075] (l)aris: again, very light insertion above the line and no caret. This was probably a correction from a saut de même au même: the preceding al ends with an l so the writer realized afterward the missing l.
