7227] trasfumé: cf. Aquilon de Bavière, "échauffé, exalté" (vv. 425/37), from It. *strafumanto/trafumato, 'riscaldato a fumare' (vol 3, p. 322). The term also appears in Guerra d'Attila, but without definition.

7278] sovragne: this word appears twice elsewhere as an epithet of God ("rois/roy sovragne," vv. 5859, 7269), always in rhyme. It only appears elsewhere in Nicola da Verona's Pharsale (v. 825; RIALFrI). The line is not present in T. Because of the frequent palatalizations of -n– in forms of venir, this could be a form with sovra + venir; cf. for example, "vagne" in v. 7270 in this laisse.
7279] marois here could be the standard OF usage, "swamp."

7306] See illumination below: merpeople, male and female. Possible source: there are a number of similar monsters in the Roman d'Alexandre, 3, 164 (for mermaids); for men in two parts above the navel, 3, 181, etc.

7308]This section seems a bit confused. See T 6988- 6900: che da l'onbrio y[n] suso estatura d'omo tereno, / e dal mezo y[n] zosa statura de peso veramente. / Dentro lo maro [con]versano, del peso vano ma[n]zando [that from the navel up they had the built of a man, and from the middle down, the build of a fish. They lived in the sea, they ate fish]. Either Turin has added an final hemistich and an initial hemistich, or two half-lines have been lost. Magiant would then be missing an abbreviation line for -n–. Another possibility would be "imagiant," looking like (from "imagier" (T-L col 1433, imagier2), which we accept here.

7312] As Meregazzi says ("L'Ugo dAlvernia," p. 19), the Roman d'Alexandre cites "li Otifal" (p. 319, l. 19, ed. Michelant), so we have divided this as "L'Ocifal." However, Harf-Larcner uses "Liotifal" (III, 2452) for "Ichtyophages"; grammatically, an article seems to be necessary in both the Alexandre and here. Following events are also similar to those in the Roman d'Alexandre (Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia," p. 22).

7701] soie might be here the feminine possessive adjective, possibly in an Italianate construction. This would be the only time in the text the form would appear after the noun. It could also be s'oie: "he also had [held] the entire time." The three lines 7701-7703 refer to the episode in the illumination at the bottom of the page, where burning masses fall into water, and spirits are led along the side of the stream; the language seems to be corrupted. Compare T 7383: Vite un monte che tuto se corla e tuto brusa, for B 7702; there is no equivalent to 7701. Perhaps it means "He called on God, Holding the cross in his hand the whole time." In line 7702, the word "sevre" or "seure" could be related to "(es)sever," 'drain, channel, ditch' from 'to stream out, flow away' (similar to Modern English "sewer"). Cf. Matsumura, "essee": "canal d'écoulement." Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 21): Si l'avoit seüré [...] qui crolle. In fact there would seem to be a confusion of what is illustrated here: burning masses appear from v. 7365 to 7398 (v. 51V, where the illumination instead is of the divided humans, vv. 7349-62), whence the griffons ultimately lift Huon and his horse to the other side.

7759] doplé: this could be second person singular; the preceding line is all second person plural in addressing Huon and his party; the following line is second person singular (as), so either is possible.

7761] T 7439:romanemo quie, "we stay here"; Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): por ce mainir a toy. Though standard OF grammars suggest that the infinitive is only used as an imperative following Or de or in a negative (cf. Ménard, ¶ 161, p. 160), here the construction seems to indicate an imperative. In Italian, the use of the imperative in the negative is and was accepted; the positive was and is used for "generic instructions" (e.g., public signs or cooking instructions; see Maiden and Robustelli ¶14.8, p. 248).
7762] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 22): "Autre non puet [estre]." di[t] le quuens demanoy; cf. T 7440: "Altro no[n] pò esere," lo [con]te dize," de presente."

7764.1] T 7442: "Ora me dite," dize lo [con]te, "a ponto a ponto, no[n] me celate: Turin has two forms of the verb "to say." Here we seem have "Ore m'oÿ," "Now listen to me" in order to keep the syllable count. The verb form, however, is second person singular, not plural as at the end of the line.

7809] Ganelon: the antagonist of the Song of Roland, who betrayed Roland, Charlemagne's nephew and the hero of the French army; also in Dante's Inferno 32.122, the ninth circle of traitors to country or party, Antenora. Marsile is presented as the Muslim King of Saragossa in that poem.

7849] arche: The meaning of this term has been debated, especially in relation to St. Peter, in the Couronnement de Louis (see Lepage; Crespo). For Noah, the question is particularly problematic; see note in the translation and line 8139 that speaks of when the arche landed.

8167] MS: Sue fenue.The form "fenue" or "efenue" does not appear anywhere else in Franco-Italian literature or in OF dictionaries. There are four downstrokes; it might be a form for "epiphany" with a missing syllable, so "revelation," which would make sense here. Another possibility might be "service" if the "f" is an error for a long "s" and there is a "c" missing; but the s/f error is not frequent in this MS. The tradition was clearly corrupt; see T 7847: Suo hofizio fazea. Stengel: Sue fenue ("Huons Suche," p. 34), with a note on p. 62, "Is somehow fenue deformed from synfonie?"

8197] anbaiser: seems to be a combination of "embracier"+ "baisier"; both appear in T 7877: Crede lor prendre et abrazare e basare cosie. The situation– affection for the departed, as in Vergil's Aeneid 6 and in Ynide's visit from her father, with an inability to embrace– has created an overlap, making translation also difficult.

8205.1] enclostre: clearly written together in the MS. This is a Franco-Italianism, by someone very conscious of language structures. It derives from énkāuston; as DELI points out, the -l- was inserted. However, one must also note that Latin -CL- (/kl/), like other consonants before -L- is normally palatalized in Italian (Rohlfs ¶¶¶ 247-248; 250; 270), the spelling -clo- may represent a false etymology on the part of a scribe.

8284] "Beati imaculati" are first words in Psalm 118 of the Vulgate, 119 the modern Bible. The lines from it continue throughout this poem; see Morgan, "Dirige gressus meos. The Psalm is also unique in its structure and length, construed as a meditation on the law of God, probably a prayer for dor deliverance from trouble (for commentary and summary, see The Oxford Annotated Bible with the Apocrypha, pp. 749-54).

8286] Scribal error? Line was written twice by scribe, once as last line of a column, again as the first line of a column. We omit the repetition. The first version, on 57Vb, reads "puis quil oit troveç par lui nët oblie"; the second, 58Ra, "puis quil oit toueç par luy nert oblie"; Stengel places the first line in parenthesis, as usual to indicate portions to be omitted.

8307] adesés: there seem to be three possible verbs here; one, the OF "adeser," 'touching, reaching'; second, a number of F-I texts (Attila; EE; Roland V4, GF use "adeser", "to hurry, rush" (cf. Holtus, Lexikalische, 178-79); and finally, Foucon V19, line 6434, "Ch'el venist in França por son cor adasier" (RIALFrI), 'to relax'; this last, especially since it also appears in 8403 where the meaning is quite clear (he had gone for a long time without ....), is thus our understanding (ad+aasier, T-L col 27, ll. 17 ff).

8320] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 39): leisir dormi(r); for the encounter with the black birds, again see Saint Brendan and for the souls in the form of birds, Saint Macario the Roman (Meregazzi, "L'Ugo d'Alvernia", p. 26); Scattolini, "'Chorisantes itaque puniuntur'," p. 335). For specific passages in English, see Gardner, ed., "Saint Brendan's Voyage," pp. 92-96. For Saint Macario in Latin only, the Patrologia Latina, Vol. 73, cols. 0415B-0426D, at Chapter 11. Several of the following points are quite similar to those in the Life of St. Macario the Roman (Meregazzi, pp. 27-28). While vol. 73 would date to sources from approximately the seventh century, the whole includes sources through the thirteenth, so the Life of St. Macario definitely precedes our text chronologically.

Dante, Inf. 3.22-69, particularly vv. 38-39, about the "angeli che non furon ribelli/né fur fedeli a Dio, ma per sé fuoro" [angels who were not rebels yet were not faithful to God, but were for themselves; trans. 8370] This line is missing from T. The first hemistich is problematic; it is grammatical, but knowing how to fish and not getting anything though they know how is a little strange. Perhaps it was something with "avoir à" originally; "A pescher s'avomes," "We must fish" [...]. "se" as pronoun for the first person plural is well-documented (see Wunderli, "Se omnipersonnel dans L'Aquilon de Bavière"). Rohlfs (¶702) gives examples of "avere" with an infinitive without a preposition, but it is unclear to him and also from the examples whether an "a" is assimilated into either the conjugated verb or the dependent infinitive. He notes that in northern Italy various verbs are used with infinitive meaning "dovere," but gives no examples with "avere." Perhaps it was something with "avoir à" originally; "A pescher s'avomes," "We must fish" [...]. "se" as pronoun for the first person plural is well-documented (see Wünderli, "Se omnipersonnel dans L'Aquilon de Bavière"). Rohlfs (¶702) gives examples of "avere" with an infinitive without a preposition, but it is unclear to him and also from the examples whether an "a" is assimilated into either the conjugated verb or the dependent infinitive. He notes that in northern Italy various verbs are used with infinitive meaning "dovere," but gives no examples with "avere." Since the hemistich does make sense as it stands we have not separated a pronoun from the verb, but suggest this alternative meaning. This is a Tantalus-type torture for the fallen angels.

Following the equivalent of this line is T 8088 P[er] lo pasazo che ly sono da qua alora avè la Crose piata [Through the passages that were there from that point forward, he had taken up the cross]; presumably its light and marvellous nature helps keep the darkness at bay-- missing here in B.

8443] Orationem meam appears 17 times in the Psalms, plus once in Lamentations; frequently appears with "exaudi" for "grant my prayer." In Ps. 68.14 is the only case that includes both this and "Ad te Domine" (not repeated, though both appear in different lines in Ps. 85, 87, and 141. Psalm 68 of the Vulgate (69 in modern Bibles) is designated a prayer for deliverance from personal enemies, a lament.

This usage also appears in Aquilon de Bavière (76.8; RIALFrI, http://www.rialfri.eu/rialfriPHP/public/testo/testo/ordinata/ot|rialfri|aquilon|006|35286/query/l#mark, consulted 09 Jan 2021), and EE (v. 14107; also RIALFrI).

8656.1] Stengel ("Huons Suche," p. 48): Un[e] grant; gold-digging ants are a part of European tradition, found in Herodotus's Histories, 3.102-105, where he describes them in India. https://www.livius.org/sources/content/herodotus/the-gold-digging-ants/. They appear subsequently in various authors, some versions of the Physiologus , and bestiaries, that attribute them instead to Ethiopa (http://bestiary.ca/beasts/beast218.htm) , and that became "ant-lions."

8670] M. Scattolini edits from this line through 10382 in her dissertation. She has generously allowed us to compare readings, sharing her transcription with us. Where we differ in reading, it will be noted. She does not use capitals at the beginning of each line, or diereses, and the punctuation differs; these we do not note. In addition her word divisions can differ. She also resolves all abbreviations for "p" with per, where we vary according to context. The copy that we have is electronic, and therefore we do not give page numbers; the line numbers should suffice, though she uses Stengel's line numbers for the Berlin version. S'ovre might be possible here: "a great worry opened itself/began"; however, we find T 8350, sopra un gran pensero, so we follow that understanding.

8975] afaitement: see Bezzola, Storia dei gallicismi (253). ; while OF afaitement has the standard definition of arrangement, appearance, or construction (cf. Matsumura, T-L), or a collection of graceful qualities (DEAF-él), Italian also has the sense of "enchanted thing"; cf. DELI for affatturare, 'to put under a spell; to alter, falsify'/counterfit" already in the fourteenth century (before Dante). This seems to be the sense here, 'magical creation/origin.' See also lines 10819, 10944.

9025] Tobler: ɾaincte Marie. Forms of "Marie" with the saint prefix appear 19 times; of those, 6 are abbreviated. Of the remaining 13, 11 are "sancte" with only 2 "saincte," so we here follow the most frequent, though overall "sainct/e" forms are more frequent (93 to 52, including adjectives, superlatives, verb). In line 9032 below, two unabbreviated forms "saincte vie" appear, so we resolve to follow those.
9026] a conduir: separated future, "will lead," typical of the northern Italian peninsula (see Rohlfs, vol. 2, Morfologia, ¶ 590).
9027] Scattolini: n'aura; T 8698: davante coluy che zamay no[n] averà paxe [before him who will never have peace]
9031] Scattolini suggests in lines 9030-9031, present only here and in T, the memory of Purg. 2. 77-81; it then reappears, in her lines 351-352 (here lines 9131-9134).
9035] Scattolini: cue char
9038] End of Tobler's transcription selection.

9039] Beginning of Stengel's transcription of "Huons aus Auvergne Höllenfahrt" (abbreviated "Höllenfahrt"). As elsewhere, only differences will be noted: [ ] indicate his emendations, ( ) his suppression of a MS reading. He edited through laisse 385, line 10079. He uses no capitals for nomina sacra. We do not follow his punctuation, and do not note our differences from it; nor do we note differing resolutions of abbreviations unless there is a bearing on the meaning. For equivalencies, see chart of line numbers.

9045] examplir: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 305-306), "accomplir, observer (la loi, etc.)," "to fulfill, perform, observe (the law, etc.)." exempliier, T-L col. 1534, lines 26-27, essempler T-L col. 1300.

9048] Stengel (Höllenfahrt): [Et] quant [ge fuy] vieuç.... dekoy (or: desroy), as corrected in his note p. 80; Scattolini: e fuy; ; she comments on Stengel's emendation, noting that his additions are not necessary, that it is enough to delete the e. In fact, no emendation is necessary; the line makes sense and consists of 5+5 syllables. For comment and insertion of this in French tradition, see P. E. Bennett, "Guillaume d'Orange: Fighter of Demons and Harrower of Hell," pp. 24-46.
9049] Stengel (Höllenfahrt): (Que) rien (as he notes on p. 80, for a 12-syllable line with a "lyric" first hemistich, 51+6)

9056] quaroy: Scattolini defines as "charoi" [carro; 'cart']. However, the Châteauroux manuscript reads "quarraus" in line 5899 (Duggan; cf. Moffat 5898, "qarraus"), and V7"quarraus" l. 6018 (Duggan). In Duggan and Rejhon, it is translated 'stone', as is appropriate for quarried material. Throwing carts one on top of the other would make less sense for building a secure bridge raised from one side to the other. Cf. Matsumura, quierre, querre, carr, 'bloc de pierre taillée', also found in the Entrée d'Espagne, v. 3569, and several other texts (RIALFrI, consulted 23 March 2021).
9051] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Vne ovre fesoie (better: F. u. o.); note , p. 80, better, Une ovre fesoie a honor (de)

9058] MS: adesloy; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Tant cum ovroie...; Scattolini: ovroie l'andeman a defloy. Cf. desliier, desloiier, "disperser" (Matsumura; T-L col. 1633 ll. 38ff., "losbinden", 'to undo').

9071] Scattolini: s'il conjuray, "and he begged" vs. "and he begged him" St. Eloy, or Eligius, was a great goldsmith and patron saint of artisans in metal, including goldsmiths. Famous for having shod a horse possessed by the devil by removing the leg and restoring it once shod.
9074] el = et + il

9137] MS: si prāt very light at end of line. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): ....,; there is no meaning in OF for "se prendre" that seems to work here; one of the many compounds (like "reprendre"): 'he blamed himself', as Huon is constantly doing in this poem; Matsumura offers "arrêter" which would make sense also which would make sense also (ll. 8-9 p. 2689 col 2), but again for a non-reflexive. I could not find this second in T-L. T: per l'altruy ridre el se vergognâ spramente

9142] Scattolini: verra; the abbreviation is a single line in slightly checkmark form, where abbreviations for "r" are normally two dots (though sometimes run together): see "torneront" just below with the two in contrast. Furthermore, there are three appearances of venra and three (including this) vēra, plus five others with "nr" in the stem, and none with "rr"; thus we expand "nr."

However, it is Huon who needs the light, together with his spirit guides, so the Creator lighting the way for Huon's pleasure seems more likely (alume).
9189] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): D(a l')un ... parfis; as it stands, the line is twelve syllables (6+6); with Stengel's emendation, 11 (5+6 syllables).
9190] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): verm(in)e; not necessary, 6+6 syllables. Perhaps he is modelling on T 8859: piena de vermy e de grandy dragone cossie

9191] Scattolini: le avis. Other forms of "avis" in this MS are generally with 'to be' plus the indirect object (lines 135, 440, 7510, 9425, 9455, 10098), or are nouns with the preposition 'a' and/or a possessive adjective (lines 284, 1717, 2762) or a form of 'to have' (3419, 9099, 9109). This point was problematic for the T tradition: che zetano fogo per bocha e per visso (8860), where 'visso' = face.

9192] This lines is problematic; it is ten syllables as it stands, but the subject of the verb is unclear, and "stranglotir" has two possible meanings; in either case something missing: the subject or the object. One possible emendation, if there were a saut de même au même, would be missing le/li a before stranglotis: "strangled them" or "extinguished it.">.

9202] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Mout [fu] felons

9207.1] MS: dovien. This is the only appearance of that form. Note, however, that doiven appears three times (7925, 10369, 11855) but devien appears three times as well (6964, 8091, 11660), so the position of the diphthong varies.
9207.2] Scattolini: doiven
9207.3] marois: here definitely the OF standard definition.
9209] T 8878: semenare, "to sow"; one wonders if that was also the intention here, "a devil sowed [planted]."

9211] Scattolini: Guillelme, as always for the name; not further noted. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"), Scattolini: d'aseger; cf. Geste Francor, v. 7128, "Qe nul falçe herbe por seger." "Aseger" is registered as 'besiege' (T-L, assieger, cols 571-572; RIALFrI, "aseger" 12 appearances; cf. MSI "segare," Treccani, Dante, from Lat. SĚCARE, 'to cut' https://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/segare_%28Enciclopedia-Dantesca%29/ consulted 22 March 2021).
9213] marois: see note, line 2702.
9215] al traire d'un archier: cf. 3602, 403, 8866, a formula for giving a distance, length, height, etc.

9216] MS: vit; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"), Scattolini: aviser. T 8885: de fero avea senbiante che·l venese bene a visare; the lack of an abbreviation line is a frequent scribal error. The construction "venire a" is typical of Italian, whereas "venir + infinitive is the French construction. Both "viser" and "aviser" are attested in F-I; in this text, viser appears in v. 6955; constructions with "venir(e) a"+ infinitive and without the "a" both appear in this text, as do both forms "viser" and "avisé" with no difference in meaning.
9219] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): [a]près (de)

9227] See illumination at the bottom of the page for the four gates; they would seem, however, to be out of order. The one to the right seems to have its gates on the ground, with a figure of a man above; the third from the binding seems to have a lion above. Note the three men to the left; Aeneas, Guillaume d'Orange, and Huon. Huon seems to either have a brown face here, or be wearing a mask. All three are identifiable through their clothes as seen in the earlier three illuminations. The female figure above the first gate holds a sword in her right hand, and a scroll in her left, that reads "ju/sti/cia."
9234] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): E qe (da ce) ...

9236] This quote (or paraphrase) would seem to be related to classical condemnations of hubris, such as that of Hesiod in his Theogony (where he relates the succession of gods getting what is coming to them in return for assaulting authority), and also in his Works and Days, where he illustrates how hard work merits an appropriate reward, in opposition to the hubris for glorious deeds advocated by the classical epics of Homer. He especially praises Justice, Zeus's favorite daughter. See http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0132%3Acard%3D1 for the translation into English (esp. chapters 255-73 for Justice).
9246] Scattolini: qu'el; here, que·l mistrent for "que le mistrent," with an object, not subject pronoun.

9249] planoy: "planets" (Mainone, Laut und Formen, p. 32); there seems to be no other attestation of this form in F-I or in OF. In T, "fede," 'faith' (v. 8919). The reasoning behind the lexeme is not clear, and seems to be a scribal error at some point. There is no evident typical scribal error, such as a missing abbreviation mark, and the line is ten syllables as it stands (4+6). Perhaps the final term is related to "esplaneör," 'interpreter' of the world?

9251] forfere: while this is normally defined as 'doing harm to someone' or 'commit a crime', it would literally mean "to do out", so 'lead astray', appropriate here in speaking of prophets whom the writer deemed false.
9254] regraigne: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 294-95), "rugir," 'to roar, to bellow'.
9255] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Qu'as autre semble, (ce) ...
9261] Scattolini: ert de menor.
9264] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): por[oi]ent; not necessary, this is a future, not a conditional, and the line has 6+6 syllables.
9265] This is a reference to Harrowing of Hell.

9268] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"), Scattolini: la versa (but cf. v. 9219, "Fasoit le jonchs tretotes averser" where the verb must have the a- prefix; v. 3216, "terre tant versa" with no prefix; and vv. 1096, 2531, with no prefix). See introduction on the use of prefixes.
9270] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Ce fu (a) cil temps; the line as it reads is 11 syllables. Possibly despoilla could be read as 4, though elsewhere in the text that is not the case.
9273] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): 'navant; Scattolini: navant [...] serra (there is no abbreviation)
9278] Scattolini: cil que la enç
9283] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Puis qu'(il) ert...
9284] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): qu'el a; Scattolini: que l'a. Since the MS uses el 145 times and il 1568, the resolution here is "il."

9286] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): pont (b: poines); Scattolini: ert, de. Scattolini notes that this line and the following three are only present in B and T, and contain a specific reference to purgatory so that they are more similar to visionary literature than other versions. She suggests that the reference to reading something in line 9288 in particular might be reading the Tractatus de Purgatorio Sancti Patricii (Ricerche, 358). For an English version, see Purgatory of St. Patrick, ed. Gardner, p. 142; for the purgatorial mountain, pp. 144-45 .
9287] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Mès en (la)...
9288.1] The second hemistich here is problematic; the meaning seems clear, but the lexeme division is not. Vidossi notes that there seems to be a damaged spot.

9288.2] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): de la dis (!) hom; Scattolini: lejera (since the line is twelve syllables without hiatus here, we do not add a dieresis; in general in this text, reflexes of laisser do not have a hiatus according to the syllable count.).
9289] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): davant [dit] je t'ois; Vidossi follows his emendation: "davant [dit] je t'ois" = "ti avevo parlato," 'I had spoken to you'.
9298] MS: anue d'vois; Stengel: anue devois.(!); Scattolini: [...] ritirt a nue devois. Anve de for "envers de" (cf. v. 5500) and vois for "vous" (cf. vv. 4729, 4875). This line is absent from T.
9299] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Huon: "[Tres]tot...
9308] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): (e)spirt; the line is 11 syllables as it stands, so would need either another vowel or to have one not pronounced in order to have a standard line.

9466] MS: ceran; this word does not seem to appear in any dictionary, but the MS reading is clear; it would seem to mean either a place or a time. Terran, terrein, etc. appears numerous times in this text, and in other F-I texts both as noun and adjective; in RIALFrI on 9 Nov. 2018, teran appears 19 times, frequently in rhyme, and "c" and "t" confusions are frequent in paleographical tradition. Mainone (Laut, p. 16), suggests that it is from the Greek κεραύνια (light bulb?); Scattolini: ceran. T-LIF suggests "serran", an enclosed place; perhaps 'grove'? But again, there is no other example (in RIALFri 'seran' is equivalent to: 'sera'; 'serena/o'; 'saranno'; 'serrando', no nouns other than 'sera', 'evening'.Terran, terren, etc. appears numerous times in this text, and in other F-I texts both as noun and adjective; in RIALFRI on 9 Nov. 2018, teran appears 19 times, frequently in rhyme, and "c" and "t" confusions are frequent in paleographical tradition. Mainone (Laut, p. 16), suggests that it is from the Greek κεραύνια (light bulb?); Scattolini: ceran. T-LIF suggests "serran", an enclosed place; perhaps 'grove'? But again, there is no other example (in RIALFri 'seran' is equivalent to: 'sera'; 'serena/o'; 'saranno'; 'serrando', no nouns other than 'sera', 'evening'). As Scattolini points out, there is no OF verb "peoner"; it is an adjective or substantive only (T-L cols. 690-691). However, "pedonare" appears in Old Italian; TLIO cites glosses on Boccaccio, 1375.

9468] Cf. Dante, Inf. 2.13; according to tradition, Aeneas had a son after his death, whom his wife bore in the woods, so named him "Silvius." Various Latin historians give "Aeneas Silvius" as the son of Silvius (Livy, Ab urbe conditor 1.3; Dionysius of Helicarnassus, Antiquitates romanae 1.71, Perseus); according to the same historians, his successor was Latinus Silvius. In any case, the descendants of the rulers of the Trojan settlement took the cognomen "Silvius" attached to personal names. Here then the "Silvian" seems to refer to the family line initiated by Aeneas's father, Anchises, whom Aeneas brought with him away from Troy. The father did not make it to the Italian peninsula. Scattolini notes that the reference is backwords and turned around though refering to Inf. (361 n641).

9471] This is the first part of the illumination at the bottom of the page. Several figures are in water up to the waist, with devils at the bottom, rocks over head. The furthest right figure in the swamp has an 'S' over his head. In the middle are the two figures, Huon and Guillaume (who is always identified with a halo, and is in bare feet). Huon is turned toward the left, to Saudin. Scattolini notes that the Br version "schai" for B's schine is a Venetian dialect term for 'armpit', which clarifies the image (she cites Cortelazzo-Marcato, Dizionario veneziano della lingua e della cultura popolare nel XVI secolo).
9473] Note the -nt ending in an -n laisse.

9572] MS: robist. For robist (T-L rubist, col. 1529), see also Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 431) who suggests a derivation from Italian RUPES, producing a landscape element, as he also says not always clearly identifiable from the context, and Mainone (Laut und Form, p. 30). However, "robestre" the adjective also appears in F-I for "wild"; see the same page for Holtus. For fagon, Attila gives "facion: .... fazione, l'insieme di schiere di soldati." Mainone is unclear as to the meaning; he originally suggests robist as deriving from a verb form, but being the adjective "wild" [Fr. "rubeste," Ital "rubesto"], each of the sinners in the mud ( he suggests "fagon" is like "fango," "mud," in Huon T and P). Tobler-Lommatsch defines "fouc" as 'Schar' [crowd, host], but here Holtus also designates robist as an adjective, and similarly Di Ninni in Niccolò da Verona's Passion. Tobler-Lommatsch defines "fouc" as 'Schar' [crowd, host], but here there is no element relating the word to the preceding one, so it would seem to be an adjective. For the grammar, the section would then seem to mean something like, "those of the violent crowd/troop." We emend to follow that reading. Note that this and the next line were problematic for the poet, both with truncated finals.

9573] MS: menistr; there is no abbreviation. For the lines 9573-75, Cf. Graf, pp. 107-108; Inf. 3. 103-105. The 'mo' of mort in the next line has been edited. Scattolini does not emend. Scattolini suggests that the blasfemant in the following line is an error, repeating the verb of this line. However, that is not necessarily the case, since repeating the term creates a certain rhythm reflective of prayers– in the contrary sense. One can invoke St. Francis's "Beato si..." or various Latin prayers, like the Beatitudes, for positive examples.

9696] Diomedes was one of Chiron's students. Dante places him with Ulysses in Inf. 26, with the evil counsellors. It's not clear why Aeneas wishes to send the (here unnamed) archer to posture before Diomedes, except perhaps because a "mixed" origin was unnatural. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Que... partì; Scattolini: que
9713] Dares the Phrygian. See note in the translation.

9716.1] The illumination at the bottom of this page is of a city with five towers visible, a figure in red (with head covering) at the top of the first gate on the left, nearest the three visitors who are at the far left. The gate figure holds a book with black dots to represent writing on it. Note that the tower is square, suggesting that "reont" refers to something else. Charere (line 9915) means both "chair" (cattedra in MSI) and "highway" in this text, as confirmed by other Franco-Italian texts. In fact, the gateway is rounded and the human figure is at the highest point. Since this is a scholar with a book, it makes the most sense for him to be in a chair or seat. The portion remaining in the Turin MS (folio 146R) shows a loggia with rounded openings to the left of the illumination, with the three travellers outside to the left. One figure inside (with a fancy headdress) is on a chair with a baldacchino in a polygonal shape (not quite a circle, but circular) above. Since the walls in the Berlin MS illumination reach outside the frame, there is nothing above the figure who is on top of the gate there. It is unclear therefore whether the Turin version is a variation of meaning, but in any case, it is one possible explanation of reont.

9801] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"), Scattolini: acorcer; that reading would mean "to shorten," but the MS clearly reads acoreer. Such an error is quite possible e/c are difficult to distinguish in some scripts. "Acorées" appears in Aquilon de Bavière, and he defines "muni, équipé"; Wunderli suggests that it is based on the Italian corredato with lenition of the -d- and the frequent F-I prefix a- (AdB, vol. 3, p. 235). However, here it seems to be a form from CURARE, 'to cure, better'; cf. RIALFrI Daniele Deloc da Cremona, Le livre de Ghatrif, 1249-1272, 46, 5, acurera.
9804] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Ugon (better: U. ch., G.)

9806] s'aonde: Mainone is unsure and suggests "s'aüne" (Laut, p. 36). T 9462: El bon Troian apresso lor chamina, 'The good Trojan walked near them/with them'. T-L has a question mark (col. 412, line 14), and Matsumura suggests "commander"; Entrée d'Espagne includes several forms of "aonter" but these seem to be based on ad+ honte, 'to shame' (e.g., aonter, vv. 1579, 2563, 2951).

9808] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"), Scattolini: nasconde; that is the opposite of the meaning, as T demonstrates, T 9464 : e de tuto l'esere lo vero li dize e no[n] l'asconde. In B, the negative precedes the verb; cf. 5398, ascondre. From Latin ABSCONDERE (see DEAFél; FEW 24,49b, consulted 29 Mar 2021, https://deaf-server.adw.uni-heidelberg.de/lemme/ascondre#ascondre).
9812] 'oscura valle', Inf. 29.65
9814] aponde: Mainone, Laut, p. 36: "identisch mit sponde [...], altfrz. esponde, indem e vortonig oft a wird," 'identical with sponde [ 9824 ...], OF esponde, where pretonic e frequently becomes a."

9825] aubre: see Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 211), "tree"; but that does not seem to work here. However, in 4976, the initial "au" reflects "o" for "ovra." In Turin, the two are, respectively, "ombra" (T 4818) and "ovre" (T 9481), which demonstrates that the original varied in some way from what we have here.

9826] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): desor par [ce] que sconde; Scattolini: par que sconde; des or appears frequently in this text, and not only are the two words written separately, but the contrast of then vs. now is clear. T obviously understood the two as one word, however: 9482... desopra sì s'asconde. The singular verb is logical for the original subject, Le grant clergé, 'the great clergy' though for the English it must appear in the plural.

9841] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"), Scattolini: heité; herté: cf. GF, line 6289; critics have been divided between "charity" and "hatred." The source however would be unclear. It cannot be "inheritance" or "heir" here. Mainone (Laut, p. 18 n1) says this doubtless is confused with "deshaitier," which resolves the issue. Scattolini: heité

9842] empuit: seems to derive from emplir "to fill," with the vocalisation of the "l" (perhaps by false analogy); this is a hapaxlegomenon as far as RIALFrI and other resources are concerned. Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"), Scattolini: em puit
9844] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"), Scattolini: mal aguré
9850] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): l'engombre (pas)
9853] Scattolini: ascemble
9857] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): ensont(!)
9864] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): dïent
9866] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): cest(uy)

9869] Cf. Inf. 4.31-42. Dante, however, does not have inhabitants in agony, but on "sanza speme vivemo in disio" [without hope we live in desire] (Durling and Martinez, pp. 72-73). T has Huon asking Aeneas if he thinks he will leave, more similarly to Dante (vv. 9524-25).

9871] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): for qu' "El plaisist a diex omnipotent!"; Scattolini: for "qu'el plaisist a Diex omnipotent"; Stengel's quotes seem to be misplaced; he has them around "E ge" on the previous line, and then before the El here, where they should also open before non respont. The two editors seem to be separating a quote within a quote, but if that is the case, where it begins is not clear. See the translation for an alternative.
9874] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): enspoir
9884] The Harrowing of Hell is here narrated first person by Aeneas, in answer to Huon's question, starting with the next line. Cf. Inf. 4.52 ff.

9890] MS: se nest devie; Stengel: se 'n est; devie and encolorie seem to refer to "substance" which is feminine, though the noun for God is usually masculine. Our interpretation is based on Scattolini (Ricerche, p.325).

9898] MS: de boin iluech; Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): de boin iluech[es] mie; Scattolini: de loin iluech mie; T 9554: Nesun no[n] remase dy bony y[n] quel locho nemicho; no other version has this line. A missing abbreviation over the "o" of "boin" seems the most reasonable explanation.
9900] Scattolini: ne crie
9905] Scattolini: il

9906] MS: non fu pas en mont. Cf. T 9562: a un castelo che no[n] fo un tanto belo al mondo. Since the following word is mont, it would seem that there was a saut de même au même. Turin also however also seem to have not quite understood.
9913] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Ja pas not(e) nosiront

9915.1] The illumination at the bottom of this page is of a city with five towers visible, a figure in red (with head covering) at the top of the first gate on the left, nearest the three visitors who are at the far left. The gate figure holds a book with black dots on it. "The figure on the tower will be Tholomé; what he is holding looks like an unbound book, or possibly a single sheet; possibly a map of the heavens; on the left side the half-circle showing may be part of a representation of the course of the stars; on the right the dots all round the edge of the page may represent stars in the center of which is something that looks like an astronomical instrument (part of an astrolabe?)" (PEB). Note that the tower is square, suggesting that reont refers to something else. Charere (line 9915) means both "chair" ("cattedra" in MSI) and "highway" in this text, as confirmed by other Franco-Italian texts. In fact, the gateway is rounded and the human figure is at the highest point. Since this is a scholar with a book, it makes the most sense for him to be in a chair or seat. The portion remaining in the Turin MS (folio 146R) shows a loggia with rounded openings to the left of the illumination, with the three travellers outside to the left. One figure inside (with a fancy headdress) is on a chair with a baldacchino in a polygonal shape (not quite a circle, but circular) above. Since the walls in the Berlin MS illumination reach outside the frame, there is nothing above the figure who is on top of the gate there. It is unclear therefore whether the Turin version is a variation of meaning, but in any case, it is one possible explanation of reont.
9915.2] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): chaiere
9919] 9919] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): studïer; not necessary, fu a are two syllables, since broken between hemistiches.

9921] 9921] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): n'isiront; while it is difficult to distinguish the links between downstrokes, "insir"/ "ensir" is the standard form in this text and the second two strokes seem more closely linked than the first and the second.
9930] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): crïer; not necessary, by counting the final -e at the end of the first hemistich.

9935.1] There are several historical figures by the name Nicomachus to whom this may refer. Aristotle's father and son were both so named; the Nichomachean Ethics, a compendium of Aristotle's notes (or Aristotle's notes plus Nichomachus's comments on them) may have been dedicated to the son. Nicomachus of Gerasa, who lived in the first century AD, was a mathematician about whom little is known. His work on the magical properties of numbers and a manual on harmonics, an early discussion of musical theory and pitch. Various other works of his were lost. Since there are references to necromacy in this section, the second identity seems more likely.
9935.2] blastemer: for the form, see Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 325-26).
9944] 9944] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): Et [en] aillons

9945] As Scattolini points out, this version may be inaccurate, since it would be odd for the door opening to be named "Nicomacus"; T gives "anbasadore" instead of "pertus" (note for her lines 1067-66 [sic], p. 366).
9947] T: Un nome scrisse sopra la porta de sussa; see Scattolini, this section complicated (p. 368, vv. 1068-69).
9948] Scattolini discusses the confusion of this line and the following in the four different versions (note for her lines 1068-69, p. 366). As she notes, it argues for T not deriving from B.
9949] a l'eperdus: Guillaume speaks to Huon and Aeneas.

9950] Farabus: al-Farabi, a great Arabic philosopher, known as Alpharabius in the West, viewed as the "second master" after Aristotle. He lived in the 9th-10th centuries and was known for scientific (which include mathematical and musical works) and philosophical writings.
9951] See translation for a delineation of speakers in this exchange.
9952] Scattolini: que vos ert
9964] Scattolini: dialetiche [e] l'autre
9971] Scattolini: ni avoir (see introduction on distinguishing pronouns)
9972] The final letter of "cert " is smeared in the center. This line is missing from T; it would fall between 9626 and 9627.
9977] Stengel ("Höllenfahrt"): tretot [com] fou
9982] sagurament: cf. Ital. "sciagura"; sagure (Aquilon vol. 3, p. 310), "malheur, accident."
9983] Scattolini: queens
9989] In the ending of the final word, an o is changed to e with a line at the bottom of the letter.
9994] Scattolini: Forte est

10003] Scattolini points out that there seems to be an entire line missing following this one: this one is exactly parallel to the Br reading that is followed by "Llo bon conte U[gon] abraça et aplaine" which would obviate the need for presuming a blank in the middle of the following line ('The good count Huon embraced and caressed [aplanir] with his two arms Aeneas who led him').

10004] The line is complete, but something is clearly missing for the sense here; cf. T 9658: Dize lo [con]te a Eneas, chy lo mena [The count asks Aeneas, who leads him]. Br similarly reads Dist li quens Ugues ad Eneas qi lo maine (v. 1117). See note for preceding line.

10014] Scattolini divides the conversation differently, rebeginning the quote with this line. The Italian "straniare" would be 'to distance', "straniarsi", 'to escape, lose touch, estrange' (DELI, "allontanare" vs "estraniarsi"), but in Attila and Pharsale we find two verbs: "straindre" as 'stringere, unire, serrare, dominare', and "strainer," 'trascinare, condurre'.We understand "straine" as from the verb estreindre.
10029 ] e above the line with caret below.
10037] This could be either "fit il" or "fit, 'il n'est'" without a difference in meaning.
10043] Scattolini skips this section with French epic heroes, to pick up later, at line 10315.

10050] de mur: in this MS, "mur" appears (8 times) as 'walls'; "mure" (1 time) also as 'wall'; "demore" is only a verb, 'to stay, remain'; "demor" is a delay, respite; and "more" is a verb form (from "mourir"), so it seems most likely that the meaning here is 'in/of the walls'. T 9703 poses a similar issue, with "de mure."
10051] pure below the line into the edge of the page.
10053] (e) is in the binding. MS: oscüe
10062] MS: sc[r](i)pture: i above the line as abbreviation.

10071] In this manuscript there are two forms: par poy (2 appearances) and por poy (one appearance), but only por appears with val and its derivatives. Mixed lists are not unknown, so I have resolved thus here.
10075] MS: cu[m] The abbreviation mark here is in the form of a vertical "z"; cf. Viellard, Conseils, Vol. 1, p. 28, # 11.

10093] These are all Saracens from Aspremont: Agolant is the ruler of the Saracens, father of Helmont, and killed by Girard's nephew Claire. Uliens is one of Agolant's judges, an important Saracen in the second half of the poem, killed by Richier, grandson of Duke Berengier.

10101] T 9754: e che (le) lor anime àno de le pene tante [and their souls have many agonies/much suffering]. Here in B it is unclear whether arme refers to souls or to arms, since the term refers to both.

10105] This does not follow the French version of Aspremont; Roland killed Eaumont (=Helmont=Almonte). There is nothing about Helmont sleeping. See laisses 286-7 in Suard's edition. The sleeping recalls the motif of Roland killing Ferragu in the Entrée d'Espagne, where Ferragu took a nap using a rock as a pillow, and Roland was tempted to kill him with a stone (vv. 3535-3555).

10108] Stengel here proposes the emendation (homes) after .jj. to follow the plot of Aspremont, where Roland kills Eaumont on the second day of the battle. However, jors seems more appropriate for that reason. Cf. F. Suard, ed., Aspremont: Chanson de geste du XIIe siècle, Champion 2008, vv. 3897-5545.
10119] quit: for 'cuit', 'opinion'
10142] canter has a mark above the 'c', like an apostrophe- meaning unclear, but definitely ink and not a defect in the parchment. T: cercare.

10148] "Death by chessboard" is a chanson de geste motif: in the GF, Ogier the Dane kills Charlot, Charlemagne's son, with a chessboard; in Renaut de Montauban, Bertholet has died thus also, and further incidents appear in the Batârd de Bouillon and in Parise la duchesse, but there is no known incident relating to Thibaut killing his brother-in-law Folco in the East. On chess in the Middle Ages and its uses, see Adams, Power Play: The Literature and Politics of Chess in the Late Middle Ages; Nicholas Perkins, ed., Medieval Romance and Material Culture. An Italian novella, in fact, insists on Thibaut's family relationship to Guillaume through Folco (married to Anfelise, Thibaut's sister, niece of Desramé), I Conti di antichi cavalieri, ed. Alberto del Monte, pp. 118-22.

10158] The illumination at the bottom of this page, 70V, has three parts. Starting at the left, the three men travelling through Hell, Guillaume in front and frontal; Huon to his left and side view; and Aeneas barely visible behind Guillaume's right. In the middle is a lady, side view, in a fancy purple dress with gold decorations; and to the right is a crowned man on a white horse with his sword raised to strike. His trappings are all gold- spurs, saddle, bit.
10177] MS: este followed by expunctuated -e: dots both below and above.
10182] Guilla[u]me: there is an abbreviation apostrophe after the two ll's, so though the name is usually spelled Guillame in the text we have added the u here.

10196] This is the first part of the illumination at the foot of 71R: three men are outside a city wall, within which (center) is a knight without a head covering, but a beard and long haïr, in flames. He wears armor covered by a yellow tunic decorated with black G's.
10203] This is the second part of the illumination on 71R, to the right. Inside the city wall, devils are pushing that same figure (in yellow with black G's) into a cave opening (Hell, one presumes).

10206] Girardo au Fraite [de Vienne] is a chanson de geste character, lord of Burgundy, Milon's brother, father of Rainier, grandfather of Oliver according to the GF. He revolted against Charlemagne, refusing to aid him in Aspremont. René Louis, De l'histoire à la légende, proposes various theories about the multiple Girards in chansons de geste.
10225] After laig, letter scratched out; again looks like white-out over the spot.

10233] We are assuming that camperon comes from the verb campare; cf. OF 'eschamper'. Compare T 9887: O tu, da quel capiron [oh you, in that hooded cape], which would seem to indicate some difficulty in the source since it is so different.
10234] MS: seit hon
10237] Aquillon: cf l. 9320, "le aquilenois", and Entrée d'Espagne, "le ciel."

10243] There are no other forms of this as noun or as adjective. However, the suffix -borg does appear, where -urg does not. "The Burgundian" is Girard, lord of Vienne, known not only for his pride but his fierce fighting against the Saracens.

10246] non vaut si is written over a scratch-out. Attributed to Solomon are the biblical books of Proverbs, Ecclesiastes and the Song of Solomon, plus an apocryphal Wisdom of Solomon. Various vernacular versions of the Proverbs exist in Old French.
10247] The bone is very hard to read because of a black smear at the top of the folio that almost completely covers it.
10258] The original could have read "por voir et por semblant"; cf. 2912, 3930, etc. ("por voir") and 2450, 10258, etc., ("por semblant"), something like "truly and seemingly."

10263] MS: S a paser. This is a problematic section; see Turin, 9918 -19: Se la penserò, el se mese questo chi l'atende; el comandò: "Dovite y[n]sire de pene tante gra[n]de [...].Two alternatives seem possible: either s'aparler: he began to discuss/talk with those whom he met. Or, to follow Turin, panser for "pensée", though it is normally masculine in OF.
10270] alas: this is the imperfect subjunctive, first person for "aler": literally, "if I went telling..." .
10305] po[est]és: cf. forms of "e[st]" and four other forms of poeste(s). T: per fare a luy dalmazo, si aveseno posanza, v. 9959.
10316] Scattolini picks up her transcription again here.
10321] Cf. Inf. 8.43-45, where Virgil embraces and kisses Dante for reacting strongly to Filippo Argenti. While Dante does not show Virgil laughing, strong positive emotion is present in both.

10329] Tisiaus: Tisias is reported to have been the first theoretician of rhetoric in ancient Greece. It is taken that he was the student of one Corax, who has left no written work. Tradition has it that, after the fall of the monarchy in Sicily in the 5th c. BCE, the rise of democracy occasioned a need for persuasive speech (command no longer being accepted). One successful Sicilian practitioner was Gorgias who went to Athens in 427 BCE, where he became a major figure among the Sophists. In the Gorgias, Plato accused rhetoricians of favoring opinion over truth, success in the moment over enduring verities. (See also Phaedrus 267a-b.) Thus, in the history of rhetoric, Tisias would stand in the same relationship to rhetoric as the Sophists to sophistry. Support for this view comes in the theory that Corax was not a separate person, but that the word, which means "crow" is actually a derogatory nickname for Tisias himself. Rhetoric received a higher standing with Aristotle, fascinated with how things break down into their component parts, who wrote his Rhetoric as an analytical guide to, and practical manual for, the art—but he distinguished it from logic (dialectic). In the later Middle Ages, therefore, Tisias may be taken as a mythical founder, an archetype for all who indulge in untruth for emotional effect. Whatever his reputation in antiquity, in this passage, Berlin, lines 10324-10351, Tisias seems to represent all seven liberal arts (10328). The reference to his singing includes another of the seven: grammar, logic, rhetoric, arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, and music. Wilfred Major, Epicharmus, Tisias, and the Early History of Rhetoric"; A. G. Hinks, "Tisias and Corax and the Invention of Rhetoric" (AEB).
10332] Scattolini: canter la usance

10335.1] This scene may refer to the beginning of the mass; at that era, the "introit involves the singing of a Psalm, which by this period would have been sung alternatingly by two choir bodies." It may be like improvisory practice where "one singer or group of singers would sing the original chant tune, and the other voices might improvise or sing composed counterpoint above it" and "vocal polyphony was used during mass, often with a low line carrying the chant tune, and upper voices providing countermelodies, improvised or otherwise." Where and when it was done and if the celebrant was involved would be difficult to verify since the specific origin of this story is not known. We thank Remi Chiu (Fine Arts (Music), LUM) his collaboration. We also thank Francesca Gambino (U. of Padova) who pointed out that "abis" as an adverb could reflect the verb "abesse" ("abaisser") in line 10333, "low(er)." "bis" in its modern sense first appears in the nineteenth century according to DEAF.
10335.2] Scattolini: biscant

10337] There appears to have been a saut de même au même in an original text here, since both B and T repeat the same verb in two lines in a row. The second would be more likely "dit"/"dist" or "fait."
10342] E 'l = et + il
10345] Scure appears twice in the text; obscure or oscure in various forms, seven times. There are no forms with an a- prefix.
10351] Scattolini: maint [et] en

10353] The identity of these devils is not positive, but Dante's Flegias appears in Inf. 8; Classical Phlegyas tried to burn down Apollo's temple at Delphi and thus Apollo condemned him to suffer in the afterlife; Ajax committed suicide in shame; Brugier we are not sure about at this time.
10357] This line is missing from Turin. However, Br has "la cités de l'enfers non paeroient mas" and P has "a l'inferno no passeraveno mais," so the context is quite different.
10361] a tas: T 10113: a tanto. The B form is "atans" (a + tant), 'at this point' (tant, T-L col 85, lines 36-36).
10363] ras: Turin 10015 reads "rasy" [shorn], but in OF "ras" can also mean "guilty." That (guilt) however would not be immediately visible to the bystander (T-L col. 1187, ll. 49ff: reüs, res).
10374] The construction of this line is somewhat unclear: croie is clear in the MS; in T the line is also problematic. Cf. line 420, cro ge. Scattolini: croie.

10376] Bestiaries suggest that the nightingale warms her eggs 24 hours a day and that she sings at night to help "cherish her young and warm the eggs, [...] not less by her sweet tones than by the heat of her body" (T. H. White, ed., The Book of Beasts. Being a Translation from a Latin Bestiary of the Twelfth Century [Dover, 1984], 139-40). That is on earth, so mortal, unlike here in hell. The oriole itself is not included in betiaries or in aviaries; see for example, the Aberdeen Bestiary (https://www.abdn.ac.uk/bestiary/ms24 , consulted 28 Jan 2021), especially ff. 25R - 63R.
10379] Scattolini ends a quote here, but the beginning is not clear.
10380] hoeç is written over a scratch out.
10382] End of Scattolini's transcription.

10385] Illumination at the bottom of 72R illustrates this scene; at the left the three travellers through Hell, Huon, St. William and Aeneas, led by Huon. To the right, naked figures are lifted by a devil with fire around (v. 10396); below, in a pool of blue, other naked figures with a dragon and little fires. Above the devil at top in middle, the initial 'R' in white on the blue upper portion, for Roger (v. 10401).
10394] Cf. the devils in pitch of Inf. 21-22, esp. 22.131, 'falcon [...]' .

10402] stoit appears 37 times; and only one other time might there be istoit, line 2684 (see note at that line). Thus we interpret here as "qui stoit." Cf. Turin 10054,"Ora me conta ch'è stà lo tuo pecato."
10406] See Meregazzi, p. 34.
10421] ensace from "ensavir/ensagir" (T-L col. 506 lines 11 ff)
10456] MS: toe. This is oddly formed- looks like 'tor' since final letter partially behind second.

10476] This is the subject of the illumination at the bottom of 72V. To the left are our three travelling figures, with Aeneas at the front this time; in the middle is a king on horseback, with gold crown and leggings, completely covered with armor and decorations; his horse is also covered with a blue cloth decorated with two lions rampant. The king holds a lance inclined up. To the right are two naked figures with bloody holes.
10477] A spot on the MS here is over the last letter; it looks like a round candle wax spot scraped off (it does not go through the folio).

10478] The Roman d'Alexandre (Alexander Romance) is quite important in Huon for its voyages into the East and for its moral commentary. Alexandre tried to rule the world and the air and seas, which was frequently construed as overreaching. For a summary of the story and information about the various versions, the basic reference work is George Cary's The Medieval Alexander. A more recent compendium is David Zuwiyya's A Companion to Alexander Literature in the Middle Ages; for further bibliography, see also Morgan, "Le Roman d'Alexandre" (2015).
10486] fou: for Old French fo (T-L 'beech-wood')
10501.1] Vv. 10501-10103 reproduced and translated in Vidossi (Origini pp. 1214-1215), without capitals except at the beginning of sentences.
10501.2] Note the assonance in this laisse, as opposed to rhyme generally found.

10509] estandre: Holtus in Aliscans defines "estandre" as Italian “estendere," which means 'to extend, stretch,' and in his Lexikalische (p. 278) equates it with "destendre," meaning 'to kill' among other things.

10511] alâ vendre: "alla a vendre": in Italian, "andare" is constructed with the preposition before an infinitive. It is not clear whether or not that preposition would be present here. The few forms followed by an infinitive are split between its presence and its absence, and a number are like this case here, where the infinitive also starts with an "a." .

10513] In the Oxford Chanson de Roland, Ganelon is torn apart by four horses and his thirty oath-swearers are hanged. Here "apendre" seems to refer to Ganelon being tied (suspended) from horses' tails.
10516] This statement fits with the Dantean configuration of hell, where Lucifer and other traitors are at the deepest point, furthest from heaven.

10525] The MS hand is slightly different here: abbreviation lines are shorter, writing tighter through the end of this column. Last reference to Aeneas is in this line. Vidossi and Aresi reproduce and translate into Italian (Origini pp. 1214- 1218, even pages).

10526] This is the scene of the illumination at the bottom of 73. Three men to the left, led this time by St. Guillaume, with Aeneas standing to the back, in front of a hairy devil on a bench. The devil is in chains crossed across his chest and holding his legs together; he holds a crown in his right hand and a ring in his left. There are other similar devils behind him holding spears and pastoral cruxes (like the papal one).

10528] MS: sensfrage, s'ensfrage: this form is unrecorded in other texts. It could be a scribal error, for "s'enrage" (OF), for example, as it is here translated. However, there is also an Italian form "frangere", 'to break', recorded from the thirteenth century (DELI); this last seems to be the reading of T 10179: De la paura de luy tuta la tera se franze, 'For fear of him the whole earth breaks apart'.

10554] There is a problem here in transmission; T v. 10205 reads, "ty et luy quỳ ben t'acordaremo"'you and he we will agree with'; The construction "Tot [et] a luy" is odd- either an initial "A" is missing or the "[et]" is superfluous.

10574] Vidossi: l'en feise "se così facessi, molti agirei malamente" = 'if I did that, I would act very badly.' But this is not supported by the MS reading because of the verb ending. The line could be emended to "ovrerais" for raise syllable count to 6+6 (cf. line 2218).

10582] Note that this is the one of the three gifts comprising the tribute that is not illustrated in the illumination on 73R. "Cum" here is Modern French "comme" which is why we here translate it "litter" in comparison to 7672 and 9408, in rhyme, where "letiere" clearly means "bed."
10588] PE Bennett has noted the parallel here in what Lucifer offers Carlo Martello with what Carlo Martello offers Ynide: bed (like litter), crown (of France for her) and ring for wedding.

10597] ferais: Mainone (Formen, p. 14, p. 27), lists this as an example of a first-person singular future with the ending formed by analogy with second-person endings (his line count follows that of Stengel, off by 157 lines as an allowance for the missing siege of Auvergne). Yet in the following paragraph on p. 14 he also says that the future for the second-person singular is often in -ais. All six appearances of ferais here in B are second-person singular. Turin 10248 instead understands as "I will never do such an order (command)," "No[n] farazo my," dize lo [con]te, "tal comandame[n]to", and the "my" [MSI 'mica'] is perhaps what led Mainone astray.
10599] End of Vidossi and Arese's transcription and translation.
10606] MS: paus: not attested in other Franco-Italian texts in this collocation. T reads "pasy", 'passes'. We emend to "païs"; perhaps a saut de même au même, seeing crueus afterward.
10619] la ci: this is an unusual construction, appearing nowhere else in the MS. It would seem to be direct object (referring to food) plus adverbial "there." .
10628] MS: maier, there is no abbreviation in the MS.

10652] faigé : this may be a lenited form of "fatigué": intervocalic t>d>ø. It is not found in RIALFrI (14.IV.19). Cf. lines 1965, 11142, faigeç (equivalents in T: fadigà; afinato [afiné = "épuisé," Matsumura]).
10664] The first part of illumination, 74R, bottom: hairy devil carrying Huon at table through the air. He's sleeping on the table, with various things on the table.
10670] End of Stengel's "Hollen...," v. 10827.
10671] Begin Stengel's "Karl Martel's Enführung," his v. 10828.

10681] quasa: the word in this particular form does not seem to appear in other Franco-Italian texts or in commentary about Huon. It appears to be a variant spelling of "casser," here in the reflexive form. Matsumura documents both the abstract sense (WatrS, quasse) and the reflexive, but not together (as does T-L). Other appearances in Franco-Italian, while spelled with the same initial form, generally refer to physical combat (RIALFrI). T-L: REW quassare.However, there is a typical Franco-Italian verb that is reflexive: squassare, "to shake up, to shake violently"; cf. Aquilon, vol. 3, p. 321, and entries in RIALFrI for "squaserent" (all "soi" or "se squaserent").
10686] This section is somewhat comic, showing Huon as a naïf, not unlike Charlemagne in the GF, who marvels that someone (in his case, an angel) managed to get into the royal tent.
10699] Stengel emends to [tres]tot; he emends to relate to Rajna's transcription of T. It would increase the syllable count to 12.

10706] fron: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 331). In F-I, fron is feminine, under influence of Ital. "fronte." This and the one in v. 8886 are the only examples of six appearances where it might construed as feminine.

10715] In the second part of the illumination below, Huon is inside a house by a window with grey outside, and his head is still on table, sleeping. Food items are on the table, including a partially-full glass, a flask of liquid, rolls and various containers.
10723] A fold in the MS runs through these three lines, across "moiller," "encontrer," "Nul"

10743] MS: sa moitist. There is no lexical item like this elsewhere in this text. The closest possibility in OF dictionaries seems to be "amoistir," to dampen, thus our word division. Looking elsewhere in the text we find "moit" (v. 7121) from "to move"; Matsumura lists "amovoir" but not reflexive form; T-L lists a possibly reflexive "movoir." If this were the case, it would signify "to gesticulate" as the text suggests already when he begs for pardon (v. 10730). The following tears and frequent expressions elsewhere about his dampening himself with tears make that seem more attractive as a possibility. An equivalent line is missing from Turin. RIALFrI includes two forms, "amoistir" (refering to preparing of meat to cook, Brunetto Latini) and "amoistist" (speaking of milk moistening the body; Aldobrandino da Siena). We thank our consultants for their assistance here.
10758] The "que" or other conjunction seems to be missing here; cf. T 10413: el no[n] pare ch'el sapia parlare [...]

10762] MS: aspë; T 10417: aspeto. There is no form "asper" or "aspre" as a noun; however, see l. 9352, sper, so we are interpreting this as a form of "esper" (cf. T-L "esperer," "esperance"; Matsumura "espoire, espere" fem., F-I, "esperance," EE), but T's interpretation seems more likely.
10765] Cf. l. 1591, when Huon recalls knowing Sanson's father at Carcassonne.
10768] Stengel: Or(e), to reduce syllable count to 12.
10781] Stengel: [au]tresi

10790] This is a problematic line; ator; DEAF "condition, état"; T-L: Stand, Zustand; Matsumura: condition; caractère; équipement; entourage; parure. Cf. line 12049. The meaning here is unclear, as is the word division; the MS reads a separation "la tor"; T 10446 reads similarly in the MS, "la tore." Since final consonants are frequently lost, here it may be equivalent to "la torne," defined in Matsumura "dédommagement," 'compensation'. Again, we thank our consultants for assisting with this line.
10796] Stengel: Qu(ant)' a

10797] MS: ay che; Stengel: Ce (n)est [de] l'enfer che je ay che[rché] segnor (based on T); since the line is 10 syllables, it can be considered as a possibility ("That is Hell which I have searched, lord"). However, with fewer emendations, the line could just be missing an abbreviation for a final consonant: cher : "It is not Hell that I hold dear, lord." Stengel seems to have the right idea for the second hemistich (there are three forms of "che[r]re" in our text for "to seek") but removing an "n" as in the first hemistich is unusual. We are looking at Turin here to help us; the "n" is thus a partitive pronoun (MF en). Cf. Line 11123, "Que a l'enfer fui; grant part n'ai ge cercheç."
10800] MS: conseler; Stengel: Conseler [vos] devéç; T 10456: Consolar vuy ora

10856] MS: se smoue. Forms of smou appear 4 times, esmou 3 times. Since the two are separated in the MS and there is no overwhelming evidence either way, we print here in two words.

10941] This is the scene illustrated in the illumination of 75V: At Charles's court (from left to right), the devil in the form of a pilgrim and Huon (with a red beard and lots of hair) extend a red cloth with golden birds on it. The king sits on a dais, crowned under a backdrop of white with red at the top. Several armed soldiers are at the far right beside the throne. Here the "litiere" appears to be a decorated cloth, similar to the definition of bedclothes that one finds on a bed.
10944] Stengel: Nus ni p[o]oit; see lines 8975 and 10819 for afaitement.

10954] Stengel concludes this line with (!?) enoy: from enoillier (Matsumura, "lorgner"); cf. Ital. adocchiare (DELI, bef. 1321, Dante). Matsumura's only example is from the fifteenth century; this seems to be an unusually early occurrence in this text, possibly under the Italian influence.
10958] Again a spot at the end of this line, circular perhaps originally a drop of wax now removed? .
10968] Stengel: [Si] tost

10969] This is the scene of the illumination here on 76R: At Charles Martel's court still with Huon in bourgeois clothes to the left with some soldiers, to the right other soldiers with another bourgeois, and in the middle above Charles Martel on the red cloth decorated with gold birds, held up by haïry devils some red and some blue-gray. Crown is the same as in previous illumination, and the ring is not in presence either.
10971] Note the parallel here to Huon's table and the devil being carried off at the beginning of the poem, vv. 976-78, just before Huon's departure to seek hell.
10994] sorjugie seems to be a scribal error for "forjugie"; cf. line 8212.

11041] MS: redue. Cf. duire (T-L), and Ital ridurre, past participle ridotto; Attila, redu = "reso" (p. 446).

11044] en region: This line is quite different in T 10695: ch'el aza fama nel tenire razone, "that he is reputed to be a good speaker." Here, the line seems to be negative in format, that he isn't married and that he isn't something else. One possibility might be 'insane, unreasoned' for in+ rage + the rhyme syllable. (Cf. "ragne" v. 6450 for "regne"; ragine v. 3819 vs. "regn(e)" and "regine"). We incorporate the suggested emendation of PEB: with "fame" at the caesura, the line remains 4+6 syllables.
11057] As usual, the "or" is written above the roman numeral.

Turin instead, lines 11086-87, speaks of supplies ("vetuvaria", MSI vettovaglia) rather than adventure. The MS has a space between "da" and "lor"; alternatively, this could read "tot le conuit da lor," 'he recognized that it all came from them', referring to his loved ones around him.

11208] This folio, though a verso, is highly decorated; with the laisse "Segnor, seeç en pais..." it is like the beginning of a new chanson de geste, with a large and gilded capital, along with marginal color in red, green, blue, and gold.

11336] There is clearly a problem with this poetic line; perhaps it is two lines run together. Half of one line seems to be missing, with a conjugated verb on which conostre depends; after ten syllables ending in "lignage" there is no rhyme, and six more syllables follow. The verb is missing from Turin 10982: zò era la soma d'alto legnazo e più grande [that was the sum of high and greatest lineage]. The equivalent would be "Ço ert la some da haut lignage plus g[ra]nt."
11349] MS: une sol; trovâ tant = trova + atant

11359] The -en- of Veneç is in a circular brown spot, which does not seem to be wax (it does not go through the parchment). This section is illustrated in the illumination here on 78V: to the left are Huon in his recognizable yellow outfit, together with a group of men; in the center is a raised platform made of wood (with balustrade around above like the supports below), with two scenes also. In the first, the archbishop (distinguished by his red robes and typical white ... hat with a red cross) crowns the king (William), who is bearded and long-haïred; in the second, to the right, William marries Belisor—they are holding hands and she is accompanied by other women. Below the raised platform, on the right, are other men, two bearded, two not.

11361] Holtus (Lexikalische, p. 227-28) gives baleor here and in v. 11238 as related to "bailior," "conducteur," or 'administrator' (T-L), related to the English 'baillif'. This is possible here, though the T 11006 "baladore" seems to suggest "ballatoio," a type of balcony, and the illumination suggests that. Matsumura, "celui qui remet qch à qn." The following line has him being presented to the pope, and thus seems to have been understood as 'dais'.
11367] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 891): tot[e] celle
11368] empois: we are presuming this is from "empeser"; cf. Godefroy's and Matsumura's citation of Anticlaudianus, defined, "appuyer fortement." It appears as one word in the MS.

11377] Stengel ("Entführung," p. 891): pristrent [il] congié, end of article, l. 11534. Begin Stengel's "Roms Befreiung", v. 11535, which he transcribes through to the end. He notes that he uses Pio Rajna's transcription of Turin to add annotations and make corrections (p. 267 n1), so we will not note these. Again, we will not note differences in trascription policy (e.g., word division if it makes no difference in sense; punctuation; u/v; etc.) .
11379] Stengel ("Roms," p. 267): Por
11390] scorceront: scorcher, Entrée d'Espagne: "écorcher", 'to skin alive'; T-L escorchier.
11392] Stengel ("Roms," p. 268): esillé. But cf. the preceding line: [...] asige, [...] prendront, where there are both a singular and plural verb.

11394] Stengel ("Roms," p. 268), note "pietà" for plait
11395] gardenaus: cf. Holtus (Lexikalische, pp. 335-36), "cardinal"; T-L gardinal -> chardinal.
11399] Stengel ("Roms," p. 268), .II. for "de"; he understands here as "two messengers" modelling upon T. 11041.

11409] The form adesie here is problematic. In Italian,"adire" means specifically "to go to [legal means], to sue"; thus this seems to imply some legal application. It could be "desirer" with the added prefix "a." adeser: to touch, reach, approach. In any case, the meaning seems to be something about what the ambassadors wish.
11416] This is not the usual sight rhyme.

11420] pogie: this is a hapax legomenon in this text. The second hemistich here makes little sense– the king placing a letter on his head (sor cef pogie) would not seem logical. A missing abbreviation line (for the final word) and/or erroneous readings-- of "s" for "f"– or a missing abbreviation– might be likely. The Turin line cannot however reflect what is here; *soi cef 'his leaders' or *pognie 'held in his fist' exclude each other. We propose emending the final -r of sor to i: "he offered it to his leaders."
11421] Stengel ("Roms," p. 268): –E[n]segne est de bone compagnie–
11431] Stengel ("Roms," p. 269) notes, "e ly" (the reading of T line 11073) for ol

11438] As Stengel ("Roms," p. 269 n3) notes, 11462-11463 should go here, not where they appear: their rhyme would be appropriate to that previous laisse, and the sense fits as well. We have therefore placed them here.

11439] This line and the next are out in the margin in line with the capital below (after line 11463 by this numbering). To the left is a large parenthesis around the two with a cross in the margin to the left of it. The lines clearly do not rhyme with the following laisse, by which they are written; Stengel notes that they should instead go with this laisse (with which they do rhyme), rather than the following.
11441] oit could be either from "to have" or from "to hear"; since this is rhyme position, there is no dieresis, whichever meaning it holds. Turin uses a form of "to hear."

11577] parare rifl: 'presentarsi, opporsi'; 'abbigliarsi con paramenti'; 'difendersi, schermirsi'.There are three other appearances of parra in this MS, 2022, 3894, 7618. The first two are clearly from "parere," modern Italian 'to appear' with the future form 'parrà'; the third from 'parere', to want (DELI, "volere") as in "come ti pare" 'as you will'.
11580] MS, Stengel ("Roms," p. 273): lay; MS: lay
11583] D(i)ex: the i above the line (with no caret below) was clearly intended, but same ink and nib.

11584] The illumination at the bottom of 80R relates to the fighting in the streets of Rome. The entire scene is within city walls, with a siege engine off to the extreme left (evident by its wood supporting structure in contrast to the continuous city walls). In the center is a religious figure in clerical garb giving a blessing with his right hand raised, two fingers out; he faces his right (our left). There are no recognizable figures in the fighting, all are in Western armor garb, with faces / necks covered (so no beards evident) and in armor, with no distinguishable armor covers. Some horses are also present.

11586] MS: mërent. The two dots normally stand for an r plus a vowel, but here an r is already present. Turin l. 11222: Allor de speto li metono, followed by a description of broken trunks and clothes thrown out. Stengel: merrent .

11763] The illumination at the bottom of 81V shows the battle outside the city, with the city walls to the left and two groups confronting each other on horseback. On the center left, there is a brown horse with a red cover, gold lions on it; to the right is a white horse with a green blanket covered with a flowered design. Above this, a man's head (with reddish-brown beard) is upside-down, presumably cut off. It is interesting that though foot-soldiers and archers are mentioned with each group none are illustrated.

11809.1] Stengel ("Roms," p. 279): Ugon [li] ançoner

11809.2] ançoner:while the meaning to the term seems clear, locating a specific origin is difficult. In the Geste Francor one finds "ançioner," which Mussafia, in the phrase "non sia ançoner" interprets "non sia tenuto in onore" [not held in honor], deriving it from ancien, so literally here, "the most senior." Another alternative is that it might be derived from "ancone" : in T-L this is a banner with the Virgin Mary on it ( from Greek eikon); ançoner would be the banner-carrier, the leader (cf. Matsumura, "ancoine"). Or finally, it could derive from ainçois, ançois for "first," here with a suffix, so the first, the leader (ainz takes numerous combinations and -er is a typical Franco-Italian suffix, particularly for a person; cf. Holtus, Lexikalische p. 99, p. 115). Bergo, in his edition of "Macario," gives it as a variant of ancioner (from ANTE, FEW) also "held in honor" (p. 261).
11810] emper: empire, empere = "pouvoir", 'power'(Matsumura); T-L "Herrschaft" = 'control'
11811]MS: escuç: this seems to be a copyist error; cf. T 11446: era sopra tuty aleto, 'he was elected above everyone'
11814] host âsauter= "host a asauter"

11837] ensent, from ensenser, to brief; to teach (T-L, Matsumura; cf. RIALFrI, Roman d'Alexandre B, 9950, consulted 7 Nov 2020). Turin reads "sapea", 'knew'. There it would translate to something like: "It was the Pope who knew about it." The problem exists because of what the Pope had promised the Germans when he was desperate.

11911] The illumination at the bottom of this 82V shows the confrontation of the pope. The pope is in red in the middle, with his right hand raised. He is on a throne. To his right (viewer's left) is a very short king in a crown dressed in blue, with his arms crossed and men behind him, swords drawn. To the right (pope's left) are other men, also with swords, the second one with his half-way out of the sheath.

MSI 'giunse'). However, with two syllables (as in i ons) the line is a decasyllable, and i appears frequently as 'there' in this text. There is no connection between the i and the o: compare ior and several other combinations in the column to the left.

12089] firant: according to Mainone (Formen, p. 27), this is a perfect form of the verb "faire." It is the only form of "faire" in the text with an -ant ending, but is also in rhyme. There are 28 appearances of firent. It would seem, however. that since this is an event in the future, it might be an analogical (and rhyme) form of the future or a conditional, which both have other endings with an a.

12104.1] The illumination here on 83V is the ordalie, the judicial combat: inside a palisade, two groups are fighting. To the left is the pope with two other clerics, one in white and one in red. To the right is a stylized tree (outside the palisade enclosure).

12104.2]stange: cf. DELI "stanga," 'long, wooden pole' used for the two sides of a cart to place horses, or to divide stalls in a barn (med. Lat in Bologna, 1253; Boccaccio 1348-53), Geste Francor, poles used to hit others. In Turin, “sbare” l. 11735 = sbarra, a pole used to block the entrance- so they entered into an enclosure, someone lifted a bar. (Modern Italian, 'spranga', a locking mechanism with a bar; from the end of the eighteenth century, a partition that separates the accused from the judges in a courtroom (DELI).
12106] This is the hair side of the parchment and in this section, the pores are visible and make reading more difficult.

12167] The illumination at the bottom of 84R shows the end of the combat: in the same palisade, the pope and various other men (not the clerks in 83V) are in the middle, with one armed man lying to the left and one to the right, on piles of armor/men. To the viewer's left is a man in a red surcoat with a golden lion; his eyes are closed. To the viewer's right lies a man with a yellow surcoat over his armor; it has black imperial eagles on it. His eyes are open.

12178] MS: douēt, douent from "dotere, doër/douër," "pouvoir d'un bien, d'une qualité," 'to endow.' T 11807: de zò che sentenziare posano la yustizia, seems to indicate that the source was there interpreted as "d'où vent la justisse", 'whence comes justice', which could also be the case here though it is written as one word and thus our interpretation.

12196] Under pde, above cristenté, a wormhole in the MS.

12198] It is unclear whom the poet might have in mind for reconquering the Empire from the Germans in 100 years (Turin gives 400 years). Giovanni Villani's Nuova Cronica (ed. by Giuseppe Porta [Parma: Fondazione Pietro Bembo / Ugo Guanda, 1991]; e-text downloaded 10 June 2018, https://www.liberliber.it/mediateca/libri/v/villani/nuova_cronica/pdf/nuova__p.pdf) which dates to the beginning of the fourteenth century, mentions various rulers named "Carlo Martello," and it is a recurring name in the Anjou family. The Cronica notes that Charlemagne's family ceased ruling at the time of Ugo Ciapetta, Duca d'Orliensa. It tells of a Carlo Martello in the 1280's (pp. 200 ff), who, by his actions in the southern portion of the Italian peninsula and Sicily, seems to refer to the Charles Martel who lived 1271-95. The Anjou family in the peninsula in any case was very important, so either this reference or that of Turin may be linked to the French royal family in the peninsula at the time of the poem.
